revision.text:
{{Molecular_self-assembly_subfields}} '''Self-assembled monolayers''' ('''SAM''') of organic molecules are molecular assemblies formed spontaneously on surfaces by [[adsorption]] and are organized into more or less large ordered domains.<ref name = "Love">{{cite journal|last1=Love|title= Self-Assembled Monolayers of Thiolates on Metals as a Form of Nanotechnology|journal=Chem. Rev.|year=2005|volume=105|pages=1103–1170|doi=10.1021/cr0300789|last2=Estroff|first2=Lara A.|last3=Kriebel|first3=Jennah K.|last4=Nuzzo|first4=Ralph G.|last5=Whitesides|first5=George M.|pmid=15826011|issue=4|displayauthors= 1}}</ref><ref name=Raval2003>{{cite journal|last=Barlow |first=S.M.|author2=Raval R.. |title=Complex organic molecules at metal surfaces: bonding, organisation and chirality|journal=Surface Science reports|year=2003|volume=50|issue=6–8|pages=201–341|doi=10.1016/S0167-5729(03)00015-3|bibcode = 2003SurSR..50..201B }}</ref> In some cases molecules that form the monolayer do not interact strongly with the substrate. This is the case for instance of the two-dimensional supramolecular networks<ref name=Feyter2009>{{cite journal|last=Elemans|first=J.A.A.W.|author2=Lei S., De Feyter S.|title=Molecular and Supramolecular Networks on Surfaces: From Two-Dimensional Crystal Engineering to Reactivity|journal=Angew. Chem. Int. Ed.|year=2009|volume=48|issue=40|pages=7298–7332|doi= 10.1002/anie.200806339}}</ref> of e.g. [[perylenetetracarboxylic dianhydride]] ([[PTCDA]]) on gold<ref name=Witte2204>{{cite journal|last=Witte|first=G.|author2=Wöll Ch. |title=Growth of aromatic molecules on solid substrates for applications in organic electronics|journal=Journal of Material Research|year=2004|volume=19|issue=7|pages=1889–1916|doi=10.1557/JMR.2004.0251|bibcode = 2004JMatR..19.1889W }}</ref> or of e.g. [[porphyrins]] on [[HOPG|highly oriented pyrolitic graphite]] (HOPG).<ref name=Feyter2003>{{cite journal|last=De Feyter|first=S.|author2=De Schreyer F.C. |title=Two-dimensional supramolecular self-assembly probed by scanning tunneling microscopy|journal=Chemical Society Reviews|year=2003|volume=32|issue=3|pages=139–150|doi=10.1039/b206566p|pmid=12792937}}</ref> In other cases the molecules possess a head group that has a strong affinity to the substrate and anchors the molecule to it.<ref name = "Love" /> Such a SAM consisting of a head group, tail and functional end group is depicted in Figure 1. Common head groups include [[thiols]], [[silanes]], [[phosphonates]], etc.
[[File:Self-assembled_monolayer.svg|231px|thumb|right|Figure 1. Representation of a SAM structure]]
SAMs are created by the [[chemisorption]] of "head groups" onto a substrate from either the vapor or liquid phase<ref name = "Schwartz">{{cite journal|author=Schwartz, D.K., Mechanisms and Kinetics of Self-Assembled Monolayer Formation|journal=Annu. Rev. Phys. Chem. |year=2001|volume=52|doi=10.1146/annurev.physchem.52.1.107|title=Mechanisms and kinetics of self-assembled monolayer formation|pmid=11326061|pages=107–37|bibcode = 2001ARPC...52..107S }}</ref><ref name = "Schreiber">{{cite journal|last=Schreiber|first=F|title=Structure and growth of self-assembling monolayers|journal=Progress in Surface Science|date=30 November 2000|volume=65|issue=5–8|pages=151–257|doi=10.1016/S0079-6816(00)00024-1|bibcode = 2000PrSS...65..151S }}</ref> followed by a slow organization of "tail groups".<ref name = "Wnek">{{cite book|author=Wnek, Gary, Gary L. Bowlin|title=Encyclopedia of Biomaterials and Biomedical Engineering|publisher=Informa Healthcare|year=2004|pages=1331–1333}}</ref> Initially, at small molecular density on the surface, adsorbate molecules form either a disordered mass of molecules or form an ordered two-dimensional "lying down phase",<ref name = "Schwartz" /> and at higher molecular coverage, over a period of minutes to hours, begin to form three-dimensional crystalline or semicrystalline structures on the substrate surface.<ref name = "Vos">{{cite book|author=Vos, Johannes G., Robert J. Forster, Tia E. Keyes|title=Interfacial Supramolecular Assemblies|publisher=Wiley|year=2003|pages=88–94}}</ref> The "head groups" assemble together on the substrate, while the tail groups assemble far from the substrate. Areas of close-packed molecules nucleate and grow until the surface of the substrate is covered in a single monolayer.
Adsorbate molecules adsorb readily because they lower the surface free-energy of the substrate<ref name = "Love" /> and are stable due to the strong chemisorption of the "head groups." These bonds create monolayers that are more stable than the physisorbed bonds of [[Langmuir–Blodgett film]]s.<ref name = "Madou">{{cite book|author=Madou, Marc|title=Fundamentals of Microfabrication: The Science of Miniaturization|publisher=CRC|year=2002|pages=62–63}}</ref><ref name = "Kaifer">{{cite book|author=Kaifer, Angel|title=Supramolecular Electrochemistry. Coral Gables|publisher=Wiley VCH|year=2001|pages=191–193}}</ref> A [[Trichlorosilane]] based "head group", for example in a [[FDTS]] molecule, reacts with an [[hydroxyl]] group on a substrate, and forms very stable, covalent bond [R-Si-O-substrate] with an energy of 452 kJ/mol. Thiol-metal bonds are on the order of 100 kJ/mol, making them fairly stable in a variety of temperatures, solvents, and potentials.<ref name = "Vos" /> The monolayer packs tightly due to [[van der Waals interactions]],<ref name = "Love" /><ref name = "Kaifer" /> thereby reducing its own free energy.<ref name = "Love" /> The adsorption can be described by the [[Langmuir adsorption isotherm]] if lateral interactions are neglected. If they cannot be neglected, the adsorption is better described by the [[Alexander Frumkin|Frumkin]] isotherm.<ref name = "Vos" />
==Types== Selecting the type of head group depends on the application of the SAM.<ref name = "Love" /> Typically, head groups are connected to a molecular chain in which the terminal end can be functionalized (i.e. adding –OH, –NH2, –COOH, or –SH groups) to vary the [[wetting]] and interfacial properties.<ref name = "Madou" /><ref>{{cite book|author=Saliterman, Steven|title=Self-assembled monolayers (SAMs). Fundamentals of BioMEMS and Medical Microdevices|publisher=SPIE Press|year=2006|pages=94–96}}</ref> An appropriate substrate is chosen to react with the head group. Substrates can be planar surfaces, such as silicon and metals, or curved surfaces, such as nanoparticles. Alkanethiols are the most commonly used molecules for SAMs. Alkanethiols are molecules with an alkyl chain, (C-C)ⁿ chain, as the back bone, a tail group, and a S-H head group. Other types of interesting molecules include aromatic thiols, of interest in molecular electronics, in which the alkane chain is (partly) replaced by aromatic rings. An example is the dithiol 1,4-Benzenedimethanethiol (SHCH<sub>2</sub>C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>4</sub>CH<sub>2</sub>SH)). Interest in such dithiols stems from the possibility of linking the two sulfur ends to metallic contacts, which was first used in molecular conduction measurements.<ref name=Andres1996>{{cite journal|last=Andres|first=R.P.|author2=Bein T. |author3=Dorogi M. |author4=Feng S. |author5=Henderson J.I. |author6=Kubiak C.P. |author7=Mahoney W. |author8=Osifchin R.G. |author9=Reifenberger R. |title=Coulomb Staircase at Room Temperature in a Self-Assembled Molecular Nanostructure|journal=Science|year=1996|volume=272|issue=5266|pages=1323–1325|doi=10.1126/science.272.5266.1323|pmid=8662464|bibcode = 1996Sci...272.1323A }}</ref> Thiols are frequently used on noble metal substrates because of the strong affinity of sulfur for these metals. The sulfur gold interaction is semi-covalent and has a strength of approximately 45kcal/mol. In addition, gold is an inert and biocompatible material that is easy to acquire. It is also easy to pattern via lithography, a useful feature for applications in [[nanoelectromechanical systems]] (NEMS).<ref name = "Love" /> Additionally, it can withstand harsh chemical cleaning treatments.<ref name = "Vos" /> Recently other chalcogenide SAMs: selenides and tellurides have attracted attention<ref name=Shaporenko2007>{{cite journal|last=Shaporenko|first=A.|author2=Muller J. |author3=Weidner T. |author4=Terfort A. |author5=Zharnikov M. |title=Balance of Structure-Building Forces in Selenium-Based Self-Assembled Monolayers|journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society|year=2007|volume=129|issue=8|pages=2232–2233|doi=10.1021/ja068916e |pmid=17274618}}</ref><ref name=Subramanian2007>{{cite journal|last=Subramanian|first=S.|author2=Sampath S. |title=Enhanced stability of short- and long-chain diselenide self-assembled monolayers on gold probed by electrochemistry, spectroscopy, and microscopy|journal=Journal of Colloid and Interface Science|year=2007|volume=312|issue=2|pages=413–424|doi=10.1016/j.jcis.2007.03.021|pmid=17451727|bibcode=2007JCIS..312..413S}}</ref> in a search for different bonding characteristics to substrates affecting the SAM characteristics and which could be of interest in some applications such as molecular electronics. Silanes are generally used on nonmetallic oxide surfaces;<ref name = "Love" /> however monolayers formed from [[covalent bonds]] between silicon and carbon or oxygen cannot be considered [[Self-assembly|self assembled]] because they do not form reversibly. Self-assembled monolayers of thiolates on noble metals are a special case because the metal-metal bonds become reversible after the formation of the thiolate-metal complex.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Bucher|first=Jean-Pierre|author2=Santesson, Lars, Kern, Klaus|title=Thermal Healing of Self-Assembled Organic Monolayers: Hexane- and Octadecanethiol on Au(111) and Ag(111)|journal=Langmuir|date=31 March 1994|volume=10|issue=4|pages=979–983|doi=10.1021/la00016a001}}</ref> This reversibility is what gives rise to vacancy islands and it is why SAMs of alkanethiolates can be thermally desorbed and undergo exchange with free thiols.<ref name=Schlenoff>{{cite journal|last=Schlenoff|first=Joseph B.|author2=Li, Ming, Ly, Hiep|title=Stability and Self-Exchange in Alkanethiol Monolayers|journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society|date=30 November 1995|volume=117|issue=50|pages=12528–12536|doi=10.1021/ja00155a016}}</ref>
==Preparation== Metal substrates for use in SAMs can be produced through [[physical vapor deposition]] techniques, [[Electrophoretic deposition|electrodeposition]] or electroless deposition.<ref name = "Love" /> Thiol or selenium SAMs produced by adsorption from solution are typically made by immersing a substrate into a dilute solution of alkane thiol in ethanol, though many different solvents can be used<ref name = "Love"/> besides use of pure liquids.<ref name="Subramanian2007"/> While SAMs are often allowed to form over 12 to 72 hours at room temperature,<ref name = "Vos" /><ref name="Wysocki">{{cite news|author=Wysocki|title=Self-Assembled Monolayers (SAMs) as Collision Surfaces for Ion Activation|url=http://quiz2.chem.arizona.edu/wysocki/Projects/Surface_Characterization/SAMs.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100622085053/http://quiz2.chem.arizona.edu/wysocki/Projects/Surface_Characterization/SAMs.pdf|archivedate=22 June 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> SAMs of alkanethiolates form within minutes.<ref name = "Nuzzo">{{cite journal|last=Nuzzo|first=Ralph G.|author2=Allara, David L. |title=Adsorption of bifunctional organic disulfides on gold surfaces|journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society|date=31 May 1983|volume=105|issue=13|pages=4481–4483|doi=10.1021/ja00351a063}}</ref><ref name = "Bain">{{cite journal|last=Bain|first=Colin D.|author2=Troughton, E. Barry |author3=Tao, Yu Tai |author4=Evall, Joseph |author5=Whitesides, George M. |author6=Nuzzo, Ralph G. |title=Formation of monolayer films by the spontaneous assembly of organic thiols from solution onto gold|journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society|date=31 December 1988|volume=111|issue=1|pages=321–335|doi=10.1021/ja00183a049|url=http://www.dtic.mil/get-tr-doc/pdf?AD=ADA229263}}</ref> Special attention is essential in some cases, such as that of dithiol SAMs to avoid problems due to oxidation or photoinduced processes, which can affect terminal groups and lead to disorder and multilayer formation.<ref name=Hamoudi2010>{{cite journal|last=Hamoudi|first=H.|author2=Prato M., Dablemont C., Cavalleri O., Canepa M., Esaulov, V. A.|title=Self-Assembly of 1,4-Benzenedimethanethiol Self-Assembled Monolayers on Gold|journal=Langmuir|year=2010|volume=26|issue=10|pages=7242–7247|doi=10.1021/la904317b |pmid=20199099}}</ref><ref name=Hamoudi2008>{{cite journal|last=Hamoudi|first=H.|author2=Guo Z.,Prato M., Dablemont C., Zheng W.Q., Bourguignon B., Canepa M., Esaulov, V. A.|title=On the self assembly of short chain alkanedithiols|journal=Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics|year=2008|volume=10|issue=45|pages=6836–6841|doi=10.1039/B809760G|pmid=19015788|bibcode = 2008PCCP...10.6836H |last3=Prato|first3=Mirko|last4=Dablemont|first4=Céline|last5=Zheng|first5=Wan Quan|last6=Bourguignon|first6=Bernard|last7=Canepa|first7=Maurizio|last8=Esaulov|first8=Vladimir A.}}</ref> In this case appropriate choice of solvents, their degassing by inert gasses and preparation in the absence of light is crucial<ref name="Hamoudi2010"/><ref name="Hamoudi2008"/> and allows formation of "standing up" SAMs with free –SH groups. Self-assembled monolayers can also be adsorbed from the vapor phase.<ref name = "Schreiber" /><ref name=Alarcon2010>{{cite journal|last=Alarcon|first=L.S.|author2=Chen L., Esaulov, V. A., Gayone J.E., Sanchez E., Grizzi O.|title=Thiol Terminated 1,4-Benzenedimethanethiol Self-Assembled Monolayers on Au(111) and InP(110) from Vapor Phase|journal=Journal of Physical Chemistry C|year=2010|volume=114|issue=47|pages=19993–19999|doi=10.1021/jp1044157}}</ref> In some cases when obtaining an ordered assembly is difficult or when different density phases need to be obtained substitutional self-assembly is used. Here one first forms the SAM of a given type of molecules, which give rise to ordered assembly and then a second assembly phase is performed (e.g. by immersion into a different solution). This method has also been used to give information on relative binding strengths of SAMs with different head groups and more generally on self-assembly characteristics.<ref name="Schlenoff"/><ref name=Chaudhari2011>{{cite journal|last=Chaudhari|first=V.|author2=Harish N.M.K. |author3=Sampath S. |author4=Esaulov V.A. |title=Substitutional Self-Assembly of Alkanethiol and Selenol SAMs from a Lying-Down Doubly Tethered Butanedithiol SAM on Gold|journal=Journal of Physical Chemistry C|year=2011|volume=115|issue=33|pages=16518–16523|doi=10.1021/jp2042922 }}</ref>
==Characterization== The thicknesses of SAMs can be measured using [[ellipsometry]] and [[X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy|X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS)]], which also give information on interfacial properties.<ref name = "Hamoudi2010" /><ref name=Prato2008>{{cite journal|last=Prato|first=M.|author2=Moroni R. |author3=Bisio F. |author4=Rolandi R. |author5=Mattera L. |author6=Cavalleri O. |author7=Canepa M. |title=Optical Characterization of Thiolate Self-Assembled Monolayers on Au(111)|journal=Journal of Physical Chemistry C|year=2008|volume=112|issue=10|pages=3899–3906|doi=10.1021/jp711194s}}</ref> The order in the SAM and orientation of molecules can be probed by [[NEXAFS|Near Edge Xray Absorption Fine Structure (NEXAFS)]] and [[FTIR|Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy]] in Reflection Absorption Infrared Spectroscopy (RAIRS)<ref name = "Nuzzo" /><ref name = "Hamoudi2008" /> studies. Numerous other spectroscopic techniques are used<ref name = "Schreiber" /> such as [[Second-harmonic generation]] (SHG), [[Sum-frequency generation]] (SFG), [[Surface-enhanced Raman scattering]] (SERS), as well as<ref name=Kato2002>{{cite journal|last=Kato|first=H.|author2=Noh J. |author3=Hara M. |author4=Kawai M. |title=An HREELS Study of Alkanethiol Self-Assembled Monolayers on Au(111)|journal=Journal of Physical Chemistry C|year=2002|volume=106|issue=37|pages=9655–9658|doi=10.1021/jp020968c}}</ref> [[HREELS|High-resolution electron energy loss spectroscopy (HREELS)]]. The structures of SAMs are commonly determined using scanning probe microscopy techniques such as [[atomic force microscopy]] (AFM) and [[scanning tunneling microscopy]] (STM). STM has been able to help understand the mechanisms of SAM formation as well as determine the important structural features that lend SAMs their integrity as surface-stable entities. In particular STM can image the shape, spatial distribution, terminal groups and their packing structure. AFM offers an equally powerful tool without the requirement of the SAM being conducting or semi-conducting. AFM has been used to determine chemical functionality, conductance, magnetic properties, surface charge, and frictional forces of SAMs.<ref name = "Smith">{{cite journal | last1=Smith | title=Patterning Self-Assembled Monolayers | journal=Progress in Surface Science | year=2004 | volume=75 | pages=1–68 | doi=10.1016/j.progsurf.2003.12.001 | last2=Lewis | first2=Penelope A | last3=Weiss | first3=Paul S | bibcode = 2004PrSS...75....1S | displayauthors= 1}}</ref> More recently, however, diffractive methods have also been used.<ref name = "Love" /> The structure can be used to characterize the kinetics and defects found on the monolayer surface. These techniques have also shown physical differences between SAMs with planar substrates and nanoparticle substrates. An alternative characterisation instrument for measuring the self-assembly in real time is [[dual polarisation interferometry]] where the refractive index, thickness, mass and birefringence of the self assembled layer are quantified at high resolution. [[Contact angle]] measurements can be used to determine the surface free-energy which reflects the average composition of the surface of the SAM and can be used to probe the kinetics and thermodynamics of the formation of SAMs.<ref name = "Nuzzo" /><ref name = "Bain" /> The kinetics of adsorption and temperature induced desorption as well as information on structure can also be obtained in real time by ion scattering techniques such as [[low energy ion scattering|low energy ion scattering (LEIS)]] and [[low energy ion scattering|time of flight direct recoil spectroscopy (TOFDRS)]].<ref name = "Alarcon2010" />
===Defects=== Defects due to both external and intrinsic factors may appear. External factors include the cleanliness of the substrate, method of preparation, and purity of the adsorbates.<ref name = "Love" /><ref name = "Vos" /> SAMs intrinsically form defects due to the thermodynamics of formation, e.g. thiol SAMs on gold typically exhibit etch pits (monatomic vacancy islands) likely due to extraction of adatoms from the substrate and formation of adatom-adsorbate moieties. Recently, a new type of fluorosurfactants have found that can form nearly perfect monolayer on gold substrate due to the increase of mobility of gold surface atoms.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Tang | first1 = Yongan | last2 = Yan | first2 = Jiawei | last3 = Zhou | first3 = Xiaoshun | last4 = Fu | first4 = Yongchun | last5 = Mao | first5 = Bingwei | year = 2008 | title = An STM study on nonionic fluorosurfactant zonyl FSN self-assembly on Au(111) large domains, few defects, and good stability | url = | journal = Langmuir | volume = 24 | issue = | pages = 13245–13249 | doi=10.1021/la802682n}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Yan | first1 = Jiawei | last2 = Tang | first2 = Yongan | last3 = Sun | first3 = Chunfeng | last4 = Su | first4 = Yuzhuan | last5 = Mao | first5 = Bingwei | year = 2010 | title = STM Study on Nonionic Fluorosurfactant Zonyl FSN Self-Assembly on Au(100) (3/1/-1/1) Molecular Lattice, Corrugations, and Adsorbate-Enhanced Mobility | url = | journal = Langmuir | volume = 26 | issue = | pages = 3829–3834 | doi=10.1021/la903250m}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Tang | first1 = Yongan | last2 = Yan | first2 = Jiawei | last3 = Zhu | first3 = Feng | last4 = Sun | first4 = Chunfeng | last5 = Mao | first5 = Bingwei | year = 2011 | title = Comparative electrochemical scanning tunneling microscopy study of nonionic fluorosurfactant zonyl FSN self-assembled monolayers on Au(111) and Au(100) a potential-induced structural transition | url = | journal = Langmuir | volume = 27 | issue = | pages = 943–947 | doi=10.1021/la103812v}}</ref>
===Nanoparticle properties=== The structure of SAMs is also dependent on the curvature of the substrate. SAMs on nanoparticles, including [[colloids]] and nanocrystals, "stabilize the reactive surface of the particle and present organic functional groups at the particle-solvent interface".<ref name = "Love" /> These organic functional groups are useful for applications, such as [[Immunoassay|immunoassays]] or [[Chemiresistor#Nanoparticles|sensors]], that are dependent on chemical composition of the surface.<ref name = "Love" />
==Kinetics== There is evidence that SAM formation occurs in two steps: an initial fast step of adsorption and a second slower step of monolayer organization. Adsorption occurs at the liquid–liquid, liquid–vapor, and liquid-solid interfaces. The transport of molecules to the surface occurs due to a combination of diffusion and convective transport. According to the Langmuir or Avrami kinetic model the rate of deposition onto the surface is proportional to the free space of the surface.<ref name = "Schwartz" /> :<math>\mathbf{k(1-\theta)} = \frac{d\theta}{dt}.</math> Where '''θ''' is the proportional amount of area deposited and '''k''' is the rate constant. Although this model is robust it is only used for approximations because it fails to take into account intermediate processes.<ref name = "Schwartz" /> [[Dual polarisation interferometry]] being a real time technique with ~10 Hz resolution can measure the kinetics of monolayer self-assembly directly.
Once the molecules are at the surface the self-organization occurs in three phases:<ref name = "Schwartz" /> :1. A low-density phase with random dispersion of molecules on the surface. :2. An intermediate-density phase with conformational disordered molecules or molecules lying flat on the surface. :3. A high-density phase with close-packed order and molecules standing normal to the substrate's surface. The phase transitions in which a SAM forms depends on the temperature of the environment relative to the triple point temperature, the temperature in which the tip of the low-density phase intersects with the intermediate-phase region. At temperatures below the triple point the growth goes from phase 1 to phase 2 where many islands form with the final SAM structure, but are surrounded by random molecules. Similar to nucleation in metals, as these islands grow larger they intersect forming boundaries until they end up in phase 3, as seen below.<ref name = "Schwartz" />
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:SAM below triple point.jpg|thumb|center|400px|The assembly of SAMs below the triple point temperature]] --> At temperatures above the triple point the growth is more complex and can take two paths. In the first path the heads of the SAM organize to their near final locations with the tail groups loosely formed on top. Then as they transit to phase 3, the tail groups become ordered and straighten out. In the second path the molecules start in a lying down position along the surface. These then form into islands of ordered SAMs, where they grow into phase 3, as seen below.<ref name = "Schwartz" />
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:SAM above triple point.jpg|thumb|center|400px|The assembly of SAMs above the triple point temperature]] --> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:SAM orientation.jpg|thumb|right|Orientation angles used to characterize deposited SAMs]] --> The nature in which the tail groups organize themselves into a straight ordered monolayer is dependent on the inter-molecular attraction, or [[van der Waals forces]], between the tail groups. To minimize the free energy of the organic layer the molecules adopt conformations that allow high degree of [[Van der Waals forces]] with some hydrogen bonding. The small size of the SAM molecules are important here because Van der Waals forces arise from the dipoles of molecules and are thus much weaker than the surrounding surface forces at larger scales. The assembly process begins with a small group of molecules, usually two, getting close enough that the [[Van der Waals forces]] overcome the surrounding force. The forces between the molecules orient them so they are in their straight, optimal, configuration. Then as other molecules come close by they interact with these already organized molecules in the same fashion and become a part of the conformed group. When this occurs across a large area the molecules support each other into forming their SAM shape seen in Figure 1. The orientation of the molecules can be described with two parameters: α and β. α is the angle of tilt of the backbone from the surface normal. In typical applications α varies from 0 to 60 degrees depending on the substrate and type of SAM molecule. β is the angle of rotation along the long axis of tee molecule. β is usually between 30 and 40 degrees.<ref name = "Love" /> In some cases existence of kinetic traps hindering the final ordered orientation has been pointed out.<ref name = "Schreiber" /> Thus in case of dithiols formation of a "lying down" phase<ref name = "Schreiber" /> was considered an impediment to formation of "standing up" phase, however various recent studies indicate this is not the case.<ref name = "Hamoudi2010" /><ref name = "Hamoudi2008" />
Many of the SAM properties, such as thickness, are determined in the first few minutes. However, it may take hours for defects to be eliminated via annealing and for final SAM properties to be determined.<ref name = "Schwartz" /><ref name = "Vos" /> The exact kinetics of SAM formation depends on the adsorbate, solvent and substrate properties. In general, however, the kinetics are dependent on both preparations conditions and material properties of the solvent, adsorbate and substrate.<ref name = "Schwartz" /> Specifically, kinetics for adsorption from a liquid solution are dependent on:<ref name = "Love" /> * Temperature – room-temperature preparation improves kinetics and reduces defects. * Concentration of adsorbate in the solution – low concentrations require longer immersion times<ref name = "Love" /><ref name = "Vos" /> and often create highly crystalline domains.<ref name = "Vos" /> * Purity of the adsorbate – impurities can affect the final physical properties of the SAM * Dirt or contamination on the substrate – imperfections can cause defects in the SAM
The final structure of the SAM is also dependent on the chain length and the structure of both the adsorbate and the substrate. Steric hindrance and metal substrate properties, for example, can affect the packing density of the film,<ref name = "Love" /><ref name = "Vos" /> while chain length affects SAM thickness.<ref name = "Kaifer" /> Longer chain length also increases the thermodynamic stability.<ref name = "Love" />
==Patterning==
===1. Locally attract=== This first strategy involves locally depositing [[self-assembled monolayers]] on the surface only where the [[nanostructure]] will later be located. This strategy is advantageous because it involves high throughput methods that generally involve fewer steps than the other two strategies. The major techniques that use this strategy are:<ref name = "Seong">{{cite journal|title=Strategies for Controlled Placement of Nanoscale Building Blocks|journal=Nanoscale Res Lett |year=2007|volume=2|pages=519–545|doi=10.1007/s11671-007-9091-3|author1=Seong, Jin Koh|issue=11|pmid=21794185|bibcode = 2007NRL.....2..519K|pmc=3246612}}</ref> * [[Soft lithography|Micro-contact printing]] :Micro-contact printing or [[soft lithography]] is analogous to printing ink with a rubber stamp. The SAM molecules are inked onto a pre-shaped elastomeric stamp with a solvent and transferred to the substrate surface by stamping. The SAM solution is applied to the entire stamp but only areas that make contact with the surface allow transfer of the SAMs. The transfer of the SAMs is a complex diffusion process that depends on the type of molecule, concentration, duration of contact, and pressure applied. Typical stamps use PDMS because its elastomeric properties, E = 1.8 MPa, allow it to fit the countour of micro surfaces and its low surface energy, γ = 21.6 dyn/cm². This is a parallel process and can thus place nanoscale objects over a large area in a short time.<ref name = "Love" /> * [[Dip-pen nanolithography]] :[[Dip-pen nanolithography]] is a process that uses an [[atomic force microscope]] to transfer molecules on the tip to a substrate. Initially the tip is dipped into a reservoir with an ink. The ink on the tip evaporates and leaves the desired molecules attached to the tip. When the tip is brought into contact with the surface a water meniscus forms between the tip and the surface resulting in the diffusion of molecules from the tip to the surface. These tips can have radii in the tens of nanometers, and thus SAM molecules can be very precisely deposited onto a specific location of the surface. This process was discovered by [[Chad Mirkin]] and co-workers at [[Northwestern University]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Dip-Pen Nanolithography|journal=Science |year=1999|volume=283|pages=661–663|author1=Piner, R.D|author2=Zhu, J|author3=Xu, F|author4=Hong, S|author5=Mirkin, C.A|doi=10.1126/science.283.5402.661|pmid=9924019|issue=5402}}</ref>
===2. Locally remove=== The locally remove strategy begins with covering the entire surface with a SAM. Then individual SAM molecules are removed from locations where the deposition of [[nanostructures]] is not desired. The end result is the same as in the locally attract strategy, the difference being in the way this is achieved. The major techniques that use this strategy are:<ref name = "Seong" /> * [[Scanning tunneling microscope]] :The [[scanning tunneling microscope]] can remove SAM molecules in many different ways. The first is to remove them mechanically by dragging the tip across the substrate surface. This is not the most desired technique as these tips are expensive and dragging them causes a lot of wear and reduction of the tip quality. The second way is to degrade or desorb the SAM molecules by shooting them with an electron beam. The [[scanning tunneling microscope]] can also remove SAMs by [[field desorption]] and field enhanced surface diffusion.<ref name = "Seong" /> * [[Atomic force microscope]] :The most common use of this technique is to remove the SAM molecules in a process called shaving, where the [[atomic force microscope]] tip is dragged along the surface mechanically removing the molecules. An [[atomic force microscope]] can also remove SAM molecules by [[local oxidation nanolithography]].<ref name = "Seong" /> * [[Ultraviolet]] irradiation :In this process, UV light is projected onto the surface with a SAM through a pattern of apperatures in a chromium film. This leads to photo oxidation of the SAM molecules. These can then be washed away in a polar solvent. This process has 100 nm resolutions and requires exposure time of 15–20 minutes.<ref name = "Love" />
===3. Modify tail groups=== The final strategy focuses not on the deposition or removal of SAMS, but the modification of terminal groups. In the first case the terminal group can be modified to remove functionality so that SAM molecule will be inert. In the same regards the terminal group can be modified to add functionality<ref>{{cite journal|title=Controlling Surface Functionality through Generation of Thiol Groups in a Self-Assembled Monolayer|journal=Langmuir|year=2010|volume=26|pages=15895–900|author1=Lud, S.Q|author2=Neppl, S|author3=Xu, F|author4=Feulner, P|author5=Stutzmann, M|doi=10.1021/la102225r|last6=Jordan|first6=Rainer|last7=Feulner|first7=Peter|last8=Stutzmann|first8=Martin|last9=Garrido|first9=Jose A. |issue=20}}</ref> so it can accept different materials or have different properties than the original SAM terminal group. The major techniques that use this strategy are:<ref name = "Seong" /> * Focused electron beam and [[ultraviolet]] irradiation :Exposure to electron beams and UV light changes the terminal group chemistry. Some of the changes that can occur include the cleavage of bonds, the forming of double carbon bonds, cross-linking of adjacent molecules, fragmentation of molecules, and confromational disorder.<ref name = "Love" /> * [[Atomic force microscope]] :A conductive AFM tip can create an electrochemical reaction that can change the terminal group.<ref name = "Seong" />
==Applications==
===Thin-film SAMs=== SAMs are an inexpensive and versatile surface coating for applications including control of wetting and adhesion,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Laibinis|first=Paul E.|last2=Whitesides|first2=George M.|last3=Allara|first3=David L.|last4=Tao|first4=Yu Tai|last5=Parikh|first5=Atul N.|last6=Nuzzo|first6=Ralph G.|date=1991-09-01|title=Comparison of the structures and wetting properties of self-assembled monolayers of n-alkanethiols on the coinage metal surfaces, copper, silver, and gold|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/ja00019a011|journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society|volume=113|issue=19|pages=7152–7167|doi=10.1021/ja00019a011|issn=0002-7863}}</ref> chemical resistance, bio compatibility, sensitization, and molecular recognition for sensors<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Noyhouzer|first=Tomer|last2=Mandler|first2=Daniel|date=2011-01-17|title=Determination of low levels of cadmium ions by the under potential deposition on a self-assembled monolayer on gold electrode|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0003267010013073|journal=Analytica Chimica Acta|volume=684|issue=1–2|pages=1–7|doi=10.1016/j.aca.2010.10.021}}</ref> and nano fabrication.<ref name = "Schwartz" /> Areas of application for SAMs include biology, electrochemistry and electronics, [[nanoelectromechanical systems]] (NEMS) and [[microelectromechanical systems]] (MEMS), and everyday household goods. SAMs can serve as models for studying membrane properties of cells and organelles and cell attachment on surfaces.<ref name = "Love" /> SAMs can also be used to modify the surface properties of electrodes for electrochemistry, general electronics, and various NEMS and MEMS.<ref name = "Love" /> For example, the properties of SAMs can be used to control electron transfer in electrochemistry.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Chemical Grafting of Biphenyl Self-Assembled Monolayers on Ultrananocrystalline Diamond|journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society |year=2006|volume=128|pages=16884–16891|pmid=17177439|doi=10.1021/ja0657049|author1=Lud, S.Q|author2=Steenackers, M|author3=Bruno, P|author4=Gruen, D.M|author5=Feulner, P|author6=Garrido, J.A|author7=Stutzmann, M|last8=Stutzmann|first8=M|issue=51}}</ref> They can serve to protect metals from harsh chemicals and etchants. SAMs can also reduce sticking of NEMS and MEMS components in humid environments. In the same way, SAMs can alter the properties of glass. A common household product, [[Rain-X]], utilizes SAMs to create a hydrophobic monolayer on car windshields to keep them clear of rain. Another application is an anti-adhesion coating on [[nanoimprint lithography]] (NIL) tools and stamps. One can also coat [[injection molding]] tools for polymer replication with a [[Perfluordecyltrichlorosilane]] SAM.<ref name= cech2012>{{cite journal|author = Cech J| author2 = Taboryski R|title = Stability of FDTS monolayer coating on aluminum injection molding tools|journal = Applied Surface Science|volume = 259|pages = 538–541|year = 2012|doi = 10.1016/j.apsusc.2012.07.078|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0169433212012688|bibcode = 2012ApSS..259..538C }}</ref>
Thin film SAMs can also be placed on [[nanostructures]]. In this way they functionalize the [[nanostructure]]. This is advantageous because the [[nanostructure]] can now selectively attach itself to other molecules or SAMs. This technique is useful in [[biosensors]] or other MEMS devices that need to separate one type of molecule from its environment. One example is the use of magnetic [[nanoparticles]] to remove a [[fungus]] from a blood stream. The [[nanoparticle]] is coated with a SAM that binds to the fungus. As the contaminated blood is filtered through a MEMS device the magnetic nanoparticles are inserted into the blood where they bind to the fungus and are then magnetically driven out of the blood stream into a nearby [[laminar flow|laminar]] waste stream.<ref>{{cite journal| author=Yung "et all"|title = Micromagnetic–microfluidic blood cleansing device|journal=Lab on a Chip|year= 2009|volume = 9|pages= 1171–1177|doi = 10.1039/b816986a| pmid=19370233| last2=Fiering| first2=J| last3=Mueller| first3=AJ| last4=Ingber| first4=DE| issue=9}}</ref>
===Patterned SAMs=== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:SWNT deposition.jpg|thumb|right|Two-dimensional shape of SWNTs patterned using SAMs]] -->
SAMs are also useful in depositing [[nanostructure]]s, because each adsorbate molecule can be tailored to attract two different materials. Current techniques utilize the head to attract to a surface, like a plate of gold. The terminal group is then modified to attract a specific material like a particular [[nanoparticle]], wire, ribbon, or other [[nanostructure]]. In this way, wherever the a SAM is patterned to a surface there will be [[nanostructures]] attached to the tail groups. One example is the use of two types of SAMs to align single wall [[carbon nanotubes]], SWNTs. Dip pen nanolithography was used to pattern a 16-mercaptohexadecanoic acid (MHA)SAM and the rest of the surface was passivated with 1-octadecanethiol (ODT) SAM. The polar solvent that is carrying the SWNTs is attracted to the [[hydrophilic]] MHA; as the solvent evaporates, the SWNTs are close enough to the MHA SAM to attach to it due to [[Van der Waals forces]]. The nanotubes thus line up with the MHA-ODT boundary. Using this technique [[Chad Mirkin]], Schatz and their co-workers were able to make complex two-dimensional shapes, a representation of a shape created is shown to the right.<ref name = "Seong" /><ref>{{cite journal|title=Nano Chemistry and Scanning Probe Nanolithographies|journal=Chemical Society Reviews |year=2005|volume=35|pages=29–38|doi=10.1039/b501599p|author1=Garcia, R.|author2=Martinez, R.V|author3=Martinez, J|pmid=16365640|issue=1}}</ref> Another application of patterned SAMs is the functionalization of [[biosensors]]. The tail groups can be modified so they have an affinity for [[Cell (biology)|cells]], [[proteins]], or [[molecules]]. The SAM can then be placed onto a [[biosensor]] so that binding of these molecules can be detected. The ability to pattern these SAMs allows them to be placed in configurations that increase sensitivity and do not damage or interfere with other components of the [[biosensor]].<ref name = "Smith"/>
=== Metal organic superlattices === There has been considerable interest in use of SAMs for new materials e.g. via formation of two- or three-dimensional metal organic superlattices by assembly of SAM capped nanoparticles<ref name=Kiely1998>{{cite journal|last=Kiely|first=C.J.|author2=Fink J., Brust M., Bethell D? Schiffrin D.J.|title=Spontaneous ordering of bimodal ensembles of nanoscopic gold clusters|journal=Nature|year=1999|volume=396|issue=3|pages=444–446|doi=10.1038/24808|bibcode=1998Natur.396..444K}}</ref> or layer by layer SAM-nanoparticle arrays using dithiols.<ref name=Sarathy1999>{{cite journal|last=Vijaya Sarathy|first=K.|author2=John Thomas P.,Kulkarni G.U., Rao C.N.R.|title=Superlattices of Metal and Metal−Semiconductor Quantum Dots Obtained by Layer-by-Layer Deposition of Nanoparticle Arrays|journal=Journal of Physical Chemistry|year=1999|volume=103|issue=3|pages=399–401|doi=10.1021/jp983836l}}</ref>

[[File:Tourist taking selfie with stick atop Pyramid of the Sun, Teotihuacán.jpg|thumb|upright|A tourist using a selfie stick near the top of the [[Pyramid of the Sun]] at Teotihuacan]] A '''selfie stick''' is used to take photographs or video by positioning a [[digital camera]] device, typically a [[smartphone]], beyond the normal range of the arm.<ref name="TheHuffingtonPost">{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/map-happy/selfie-stick_b_6074954.html |title=In Defense of the Selfie Stick|publisher= TheHuffingtonPost.com, Inc |date=2014-10-30 |access-date=2014-11-27}}</ref> This allows for shots to be taken at angles and distances that would not have been possible with the human arm by itself. The sticks are typically extensible, with a handle on one end and an adjustable clamp on the other end to hold the device in place.<ref name="Business Insider Inc">{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/selfie-sticks-are-selling-out-everywhere-2014-12|title=Selfie Sticks Are Selling Out Everywhere |publisher=Business Insider Inc |date=2014-12-31 |access-date=2017-09-03}}</ref> Some are connected to a smartphone via its [[jack plug]], while others are tethered using [[Bluetooth]] controls. The connection between the device and the selfie stick lets the user decide when to take the picture or start recording a video by clicking a button located on the handle.<ref name="Business Insider Inc"/> Models designed for [[compact camera]]s have a mirror behind the viewscreen so that the shot can be lined up.<ref name="TNW">{{cite web|url=https://thenextweb.com/gadgets/2013/11/26/kogan-ceo-pokes-fun-facebook-chief-zuckerberg-selfie-stick/ |title=Zuckerberg Selfie Stick |publisher=The Next Web, Inc |date=2013-11-26 |access-date=2014-11-26}}</ref><ref name="International Business Times AU">{{cite web |url=http://au.ibtimes.com/articles/525798/20131128/facebook-kogan-australia-zuckerberg-selfie-stick-mark.htm#.VHeazdLF-I4 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20141130022833/http://au.ibtimes.com/articles/525798/20131128/facebook-kogan-australia-zuckerberg-selfie-stick-mark.htm%23.VHeazdLF-I4#.VHeazdLF-I4 |archive-date=2014-11-30 |dead-url=yes |title=Would You Buy a Zuckerberg Selfie Stick? |publisher=International Business Times AU |date=2013-11-28 |access-date=2014-11-26 }}</ref>
In contrast to a monopod for stabilising a camera on the ground, a selfie stick's arm is thickest and strongest at the opposite end from the camera in order to provide better grip and balance when held aloft.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Five Fun Little Gadgets|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/09/technology/09pogue-email.html?|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2007-08-09|access-date = 2015-07-29|issn = 0362-4331|first = David|last = Pogue}}</ref> Safety concerns and the inconvenience the product causes to others have resulted in them being banned at many venues, including all [[Disney Parks]], both [[Universal Studios Orlando]], and [[Universal Studios Hollywood|Hollywood]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Welch|first1=Chris|title=Selfie sticks are no longer welcome at Disney theme parks|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/6/26/8851671/disney-world-bans-selfie-sticks|website=theverge.com|publisher=The Verge|accessdate=5 October 2015}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Completely expanded Selfie Stick.jpg|thumb|upright=0.3|A fully extended selfie stick with a smartphone attached]]
Homemade selfie sticks could date back as early as 1925. A photo from that year shows a man taking a photograph of himself and his wife, with the aid of a long pole which is pointed towards the camera and out of frame. Amateur box cameras of the period would not have been able to capture a self-portrait in focus when held at arm's length, requiring photographers to use [[remote shutter]] devices such as cables or sticks.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/blogs-trending-30550998|title=Does this 90-year-old photo show the world's first 'selfie stick'?|work=BBC Trending|last= Wendling|first=Mike|date=February 19, 2014|access-date=July 31, 2015}}</ref>
A device which has been likened to the selfie stick appears in the 1969 Czechoslovak sci-fi film ''[[I Killed Einstein, Gentlemen]]''. One character holds a silver stick in front of herself and another character, smiles at the end of the stick as it produces a camera flash, and immediately unfurls a printed photograph of the pair from the stick's handle.<ref>https://www.theverge.com/2016/3/3/11157362/sci-fi-film-selfie-stick-1970</ref>
The 1983 "[[Minolta]] [[Disc film|Disc]]-7" camera had a convex mirror on its front to allow the composition of self-portraits, and its packaging showed the camera mounted on a stick while used for such a purpose.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.museumoftechnology.org.uk/expand.php?key=1139|title=MINOLTA DISC-7 CAMERA, 1983|work=museumoftechnology.org.uk|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150131002358/http://www.museumoftechnology.org.uk/expand.php?key=1139|archivedate=2015-01-31|df=}}</ref> A "telescopic extender" for compact handheld cameras was patented by Ueda Hiroshi and Mima Yujiro in 1983,<ref>{{patent|US|4530580|"Telescopic extender for supporting compact camera"}}</ref> and a Japanese selfie stick was featured in a 1995 book of [[Chindōgu|"101 Un-Useless Japanese Inventions"]]. While dismissed as a "useless invention" at the time, the selfie stick later gained global popularity in the 21st century.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.distractify.com/alex-scola/but-first/|title=Turns Out Japan Invented The 'Selfie-Stick' 20 Years Ago|author=Alex Scola|work=Distractify|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150109130439/http://news.distractify.com/alex-scola/but-first/|archivedate=2015-01-09|df=}}</ref>
Canadian inventor [[Wayne Fromm]] patented his ''Quik Pod'' in 2005<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/technology/shortcuts/2015/jan/11/meet-the-man-who-invented-the-selfie-stick | date = 11 January 2015 | access-date = 12 January 2015 | first = Leo | last = Benedictus | newspaper = [[The Guardian]] | title = Is this man responsible for inventing the selfie stick? }}</ref><ref>{{USPTO Patent |patnum=7684694 |title=Apparatus for supporting a camera and method for using the apparatus}}</ref> and becoming commercially available in the United States the following year.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Quick family photos with Quik Pod|url = http://www.popgadget.net/2006/12/quick_photos_wi.php|website = www.popgadget.net|access-date = 2015-07-29|publisher = Popgadget Personal Technology for Women|date = 2006-12-21}}</ref> In 2012, Yeong-Ming Wang filed a patent for a "multi-axis omni-directional shooting extender" capable of holding a smartphone,<ref>{{Citation|last=Wang|first=Yeong-Ming|title=Multi-axis omni-directional shooting extender|date=2013-05-21|url=http://worldwide.espacenet.com/publicationDetails/biblio;jsessionid=EQhUHRN7-NfBm8fzSJQnnxz-.espacenet_levelx_prod_1?FT=D&date=20130521&DB=EPODOC&locale=en_EP&CC=TW&NR=M453774U&KC=U&ND=4|last2=Wang|first2=Ji-Yang|accessdate=2016-02-28}}</ref> which won a silver medal at the 2013 [[Concours Lepine]].<ref>{{Citation|last=Joshua Wang|title=Joshua on French TV Channel TF1 Prime Time VID 20130511 192811|date=2014-09-10|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2H6Pv_Qq-wY|accessdate=2016-02-28}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Joshua Wang|title=2013 Concours Lepine CNA News report|date=2014-03-05|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S2VKDiVwC5I|accessdate=2016-02-28}}</ref> The term "selfie stick" did not become widely used until 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Selfie stick|url = https://www.google.com/trends/explore#q=selfie%2520stick|accessdate = 2015-07-29|publisher = |website = Google Trends}}</ref> Extended forms of selfie sticks can hold laptop computers to take selfies from a webcam.<ref name="SelfieCLicks">{{cite web|url=http://selfieclicks.net/selfie-stick-for-macbook.html |title=Selfie stick for MacBook|publisher= selfieclicks.net/ |date=2016-03-10 |access-date=2016-03-22}}</ref> By the fall of 2015 technology news noted that there was a large variety of selfie sticks available on the market; Molly McCugh of ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' magazine wrote in October 2015, "Some are very, very long; some aren't so long; some are bedazzled. Some look like hands. Some are spoons. But they are all, at the end of the day, one thing: A stick that takes selfies." <ref name="HEARST MAGAZINE.">{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2015/10/whats-next-for-the-selfie-stick/ |title=The Cutthroat Race to Build the Ultimate Selfie Stick |publisher=WIRED MAGAZINE |date=2015-10-25 |access-date=2017-09-03}}</ref>
The selfie stick was listed in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine's 25 best inventions of 2014.<ref name="TIME INC.">{{cite web|url=http://time.com/3594971/the-25-best-inventions-of-2014/item/the-selfie-streamliners/ |title=Time 25 best inventions of 2014 |publisher=TIME INC. |date=2014-11-20 |access-date=2014-11-28}}</ref> While the ''[[New York Post]]'' named the selfie stick the most controversial gift of 2014. <ref name="NY POST">{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2014/12/17/why-the-selfie-stick-is-the-most-controversial-gift-of-2014/ |title=Why the selfie stick is 2014's most controversial gift |publisher=THE New York POST |date=2014-12-17|access-date=2017-08-30}}</ref> At the end of December 2014, [[Bloomberg News]] noted that selfie sticks had ruled the 2014 holiday season as the “must-have” gift of the year. <ref name="BLOOMBERG">{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-12-31/selfie-sticks-rule-holiday-season-as-musthave-accessory |title=Selfie Sticks Rule Holiday Season as Must-Have Accessory |publisher=BLOOMBERG |date=2014-12-31|access-date=2017-09-03}}</ref> The selfie stick has been criticized for its association with the perceived [[narcissism]] and self-absorption of contemporary society, with commentators in 2015 dubbing the tool the "Narcisstick"<ref name="Carr1">{{cite news|last1=Carr|first1=David|title=Selfies on a Stick, and the Social-Content Challenge for the Media|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/05/business/media/selfies-on-a-stick-and-the-social-content-challenge-for-the-media.html?partner=rss&emc=rss&_r=2|accessdate=18 February 2015|work=The New York Times|date=4 January 2015}}</ref> or "Wand of Narcissus".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Haslett|first1=Emma|title=The selfie stick: A short history of this year's most popular Christmas present|url=http://www.cityam.com/206530/selfie-stick-short-history-years-most-popular-christmas-present|publisher=City A.M.|access-date=17 January 2015}}</ref> Despite various bans, selfie sticks proved so popular that a selfie stick store was opened in [[Times Square]] during the summer of 2015.<ref name="Travel and Leisure">{{cite web|url=http://www.travelandleisure.com/articles/selfie-stick-store-times-square-new-york |title=Times Square Has A Selfie Stick Store |publisher=TIME INC. |date=2015-06-30 |access-date=2017-08-30}}</ref> In 2016 it was reported that [[Coca-Cola]] had created a "selfie bottle" with an attached camera that takes pictures when it's tipped for drinking.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.cnet.com/news/coke-invents-bottle-selfie-camera/ | date = 17 November 2016 | access-date = 16 August 2017 | title = Coke invents the 'selfie bottle'}}</ref>
==Usage== [[File:Reporter_using_Selfie-Stick_for_Interviews.jpg|thumb|left|Reporter Vanessa Lua using a selfie stick instead of a [[camera operator]] for an interview]] One is able to attach their device to the end of the selfie stick and then extend it beyond the normal reach of the arm. Different models of stick are triggered in various ways, such as pressing a button on the stick handle which is connected to the device (usually using the [[jack plug]]), pressing a button on a wireless remote (often via [[Bluetooth]]), using the camera's built-in timer, or making a sound for the device to sense it for it to then start recording a video or taking a picture.
The smartphone's physical means of triggering the camera, such as the sound volume controls or the touchscreen camera button of the device, are replicated on [[headphones]] with on-cord controls. When selfie sticks are plugged into the [[jack plug]], they are seen by the device as headphones.
The selfie stick gives more practical use in situations that require assistance for taking photos/videos at difficult angles that need to be taken from an extended, elevated distance beyond the arm’s reach. It allows the user to take photos and videos in otherwise dangerous or impossible situations, such as recording footage inside a very deep hole, over a cliff, or simply at an angle that is too far away from the user.
==Bans and restrictions== [[File:No selfie sticks sign, Museum of Brisbane, 2015.jpg|thumb|upright|A "no selfie sticks" sign at the [[Museum of Brisbane]], 2015]] Despite the selfie stick being one of the most popular items among tourists and families, bans and restrictions on its use have been imposed across a range of public venues generally on the grounds of safety and inconvenience to others.
'''Concert venues''' and some music festivals in the United States, Australia<ref name=Grubb1/> and the United Kingdom have banned the use of selfie sticks. Organisers have cited their role in the "illegal recording" of bands' sets, and the inconvenience and safety issues to fellow audience members.<ref name=Grubb1>{{cite news|last1=Grubb|first1=Ben|title=Australian venues ban 'narcissistic' selfie sticks|url=http://www.smh.com.au/digital-life/digital-life-news/australian-venues-ban-narcissistic-selfie-sticks-20150224-13ma46.html|accessdate=24 February 2015|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=24 February 2015}}</ref>
'''Museums, galleries'''<ref name="Dunn1">{{cite news|last1=Dunn|first1=Mark|title=Galleries ban selfie sticks because of risk to artworks and patrons|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/galleries-ban-selfie-sticks-because-of-risk-to-artworks-and-patrons/story-e6frg6n6-1227221919576|accessdate=18 February 2015|work=The Australian|date=16 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="gallery">{{Cite web|url = https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-31829535|title = The National Gallery in London bans selfie sticks|date = 11 March 2015|access-date = 11 March 2015|website = BBC News|publisher = The British Broadcasting Company|last = |first = }}</ref> '''and historical sites'''<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url = https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-london-32480069|title = Wimbledon: Selfie sticks banned from tennis championship|last = |first = |date = 27 April 2015|work = BBC|access-date = 4 May 2015|via = }}</ref> such as the [[Palace of Versailles]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.chateauversailles.fr/plan-your-visit/visit-routes-and-advice|title=Visit routes and advice|last=|first=|date=|website=Chateau de Versailles|access-date=20 April 2018}}</ref> have banned the sticks because of concerns about possible damage to priceless artworks and other objects.<ref name="Dunn1" /><ref name="gallery" />
'''Theme parks''', including [[Walt Disney World Resort]],<ref name="disneyban">{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2015/06/26/disney-selfie-stick-ban/29333857/ |title=Disney joins growing number of venues banning selfie sticks |publisher=USA Today |date=26 June 2015 |access-date=26 June 2015 |author=Jervis, Rick}}</ref> [[Six Flags]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foxnews.com/travel/2015/07/23/six-flags-ban-selfie-sticks-at-all-theme-park-locations/ |title=Six Flags bans selfie sticks at all theme park locations |publisher=Fox News |date=July 24, 2015 |access-date=July 24, 2015 |author=}}</ref> [[Universal Orlando]], and [[Universal Studios Hollywood]] have banned selfie sticks. The sticks have always been banned on rides at Disney World for safety reasons, but after a number of instances where rides had to be stopped because of a guest pulling out a selfie stick in mid-ride, such as incidents on [[California Screamin']] and [[Big Thunder Mountain Railroad]], Disney issued a park-wide ban on the accessories.<ref name="disneyban" />
'''Sporting events''' have banned selfie sticks both for their "nuisance value" and for interfering with other spectators' enjoyment<ref name=":0" /> or view.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tottenham Hotspur in 'selfie stick' stadium ban|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-30719592|accessdate=7 January 2015|work=BBC News|date=7 January 2015}}</ref> The Australia [[Tour Down Under]] banned the devices citing "harm to cyclists, officials and yourself".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2015/01/25/take_that_selfie_stick_and_stick_it/|title=Oi, Aussie sports fans! Take that selfie stick and stick it|work=theregister.co.uk}}</ref> [[Emirates Stadium]], home of the [[Arsenal Football Club]], bans "any object that could be used as a weapon or could compromise public safety", and regards selfie sticks as such an item.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2900868/Tottenham-Arsenal-agree-ban-selfie-sticks-grounds-fans-complaints.html |title=Arsenal and Tottenham Hotspur ban 'selfie sticks' from grounds after fans' complaints |author=Matt Barlow |date=January 7, 2015}}</ref>
In 2014, [[South Korea]]'s radio management agency issued regulations banning sale of unregistered selfie sticks that use Bluetooth technology to trigger the camera, as any such device sold in South Korea is considered a "telecommunications device" and must be tested by and registered with the agency.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-30274974|title=Selfie-stick sellers face fines in South Korea|publisher=BBC News|date=1 December 2014}}</ref> In 2015, [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] banned them from a [[Apple Worldwide Developers Conference|WWDC]] Developers Conference, though didn't explicitly state why.<ref name=Goldman>{{cite news|last1=Goldman|first1=David|title=Apple bans selfie sticks|url=http://money.cnn.com/2015/04/14/technology/apple-selfie-sticks/index.html?iid=obnetwork|accessdate=24 April 2015|publisher=CNN|date=14 April 2015}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of selfie-related injuries and deaths]]
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Selfie sticks}} * [http://www.google.com/patents/US4530580 Telescopic extender for supporting compact camera] (Priority date : 1983-01-18) - Google Patents
[[Category:2010s fads and trends]] [[Category:Japanese inventions]] [[Category:Mobile phones]] [[Category:Photography equipment]] [[Category:Self-portraits]] [[Category:Portrait photography]]

revision.text:
<!-- source for "key_people": http://www.spaceimagingme.com/content/Downloads/news/2-11-06-NS.pdf --> {{Infobox company | name = Space Imaging Middle East | logo = Space Imaging Middle East corporate logo.png | type = Regional Affiliate of [[GeoEye]] | foundation = 1997 | location = [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]] | key_people = Mohammed El-Kadi, Managing Director | revenue = | num_employees = | homepage = [http://www.spaceimagingme.com SpaceImagingME.com] }} '''Space Imaging Middle East LLC''' (SIME) is a regional affiliate of [[DigitalGlobe]], the largest commercial remote sensing company in the world.
Established in 1997, SIME started off by introducing high-resolution satellite imagery to the [[Middle East]] region, operating from government-run [[ground station]]s. Today, SIME, headquartered in the [[United Arab Emirates]], is a leading [[Geographic information system|Geo-Spatial and GIS]] solutions provider throughout the Middle East, the [[Persian Gulf]], [[Eastern Africa]] and [[Central Asia]].
SIME's products and services include [[photogrammetry]], [[map]]ping, GIS, 3D models, [[imagery analysis]] and reporting software, [[vehicle tracking system|vehicle tracking]], [[Consultant|consulting]], and training, among others. SIME engages in technology partnerships with leading technology companies, and owns and operates a wide range of sources for [[satellite]] and [[aerial imagery]].
The company's profile was raised during the 2003 [[Iraq War]], when high-resolution [[satellite imagery]] licensed from SIME was used by some news organizations to give the public "bird's eye views" of various key Iraqi locations, such as [[Fallujah]], and [[Bagdhad]].
In 2003 SIME supplied 1-meter resolution imagery of [[Afghanistan]] to the [[United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime]] (UNODC), as part of a survey to monitor the production of illicit crops.<ref>http://www.spaceimagingme.com/content/Downloads/news/29-Oct-2003.pdf</ref>
==Remote sensing technology== SIME offers imagery collected from various [[earth observation satellite]]s and aerial sensors, with resolutions varying from 15 centimeters to 20 meters. SIME's [[satellite constellation]] includes the [[Indian Remote Sensing satellite]] (IRS), [[IKONOS]] and [[CARTOSAT]] satellites. SIME controls its satellite constellation via a ground station based in the [[UAE]]. The Company also has an aircraft permanently stationed in the region to collect aerial imagery.<ref>http://www.spaceimagingme.com/content/Sensors/index.asp</ref>
==Partners and subsidiaries== SIME is the main investor of [[European Space Imaging]] in [[Munich, Germany]], which gives SIME direct access to the latest in European satellite technology.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.euspaceimaging.com/content/About/index.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-02-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070708065129/http://www.euspaceimaging.com/content/about/index.asp |archivedate=2007-07-08 |df= }}</ref> SIME has partnered with the [[German Aerospace Center]] (DLR) to operate the ground station and to develop hosting and delivery systems of data. It has also teamed up with [[GAF AG]] of Munich to provide specialized [[remote sensing|remote-sensing]] studies. SIME has established a joint venture with [[Sanborn map|Sanborn Incorporated]] to provide aerial imaging products and advanced modeling solutions. In the [[Far East]], the Company has teamed up with [[Mappoint Asia]] to provide vehicle and asset tracking systems.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spaceimagingme.com/content/Tech%20Partners/index.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-02-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041103094050/http://spaceimagingme.com/content/tech%20partners/index.asp |archivedate=2004-11-03 |df= }}</ref>
==Satellite coverage area== Having direct access to two receiving stations in Germany and UAE, SIME’s satellite reach extensively covers an area extending from the [[Arctic Circle]] in the north to the Persian Gulf region in the south and from the [[Indian Ocean]] in the east to the [[Atlantic Ocean]] in the west. SIME has a substantial satellite and aerial imagery archive, and owns all the images in its database which contain multiple covers of the region spanning a period of several years.
==Applications== SIME offers applications to a variety of industries in both the government and commercial sectors. These include:
*Aviation *Environment Protection *Mapping *Military & Intelligence *Oil & Gas *Security & Relief *Telecommunications *Urban Planning & Infrastructure Development
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.spaceimagingme.com SIME corporate website] *[http://www.geoeye.com/CorpSite/ GeoEye corporate website]
{{United Arab Emirates space program}}

revision.text:
'''Sputter cleaning''' is the cleaning of a solid surface in a [[vacuum]] by using physical [[sputtering]] of the surface. Sputter cleaning is often used in [[vacuum deposition]] and [[ion plating]]. In 1955 Farnsworth, Schlier, George, and Burger reported using sputter cleaning in an ultra-high-vacuum system to prepare ultra-clean surfaces for low-energy electron-diffraction (LEED) studies.<ref>H.E. Farnsworth, R.E. Schlier, T.H. George, and R.M. Burger, J. Appl. Phys., 26, 252 (1955); also J. Appl. Phys., 29, 1150 (1958); also G.S. Anderson and Roger M. Moseson, “Method and Apparatus for Cleaning by Ionic Bombardment,” U.S. Patent #3,233,137 (filed Aug. 28, 1961) (Feb.1, 1966)</ref> Sputter cleaning became an integral part of the [[ion plating]] process. Sputter cleaning has some potential problems such as overheating, gas incorporation in the surface region, bombardment (radiation) damage in the surface region, and the roughening of the surface, particularly if ''over done.'' It is important to have a ''clean'' [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]] in order to not continually recontaminate the surface during sputter cleaning. Redeposition of sputtered material on the substrate can also give problems, especially at high sputtering pressures.
Sputtering of the surface of a compound or alloy material can result in the surface composition being changed. Often the species with the least mass or the highest [[vapor pressure]] is the one preferentially sputtered from the surface.
== See also == * [[Plasma cleaning]] * [[Parts cleaning]]
==References== <references/>
{{tech-stub}}
[[Category:Chemical processes]] [[Category:Thin film deposition]] [[Category:Cleaning methods]]
