revision.text:
'''Supercow''' (or '''super cow''') is a term used in the [[dairy|dairy industry]] to denote lines or individual animals that have superior [[milk]] production: that is, which produce more milk per day, or in some cases produce more fat per gallon of milk. <ref>[http://www.csiro.au/people/Alan.Bell--ci_pubHist-1.html Biology of the super cow. Dairy Journal. November: 26-30.]</ref><ref>[http://www.doobybrain.com/2008/02/15/belgian-blue-meet-the-super-cow/ Belgian Blue "super cow" breed] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090923004521/http://www.doobybrain.com/2008/02/15/belgian-blue-meet-the-super-cow/ |date=2009-09-23 }}</ref>
Until recently, supercows have been developed through [[selective breeding]] - either traditional breeding or, since the 1960s, [[artificial insemination]]. Now the term tends to be applied to cows that have been genetically altered or whose genome has been studied in order to improve breeding.<ref>[http://home.intekom.com/tm_info/rw80414.htm#South South African scientists plan "super cow" clone]</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Cattle]] [[Category:Dairy farming]] [[Category:Intensive farming]]

{{Infobox officeholder |name = Susan Wojcicki |image = File:Susan Wojcicki at TechCrunch Disrupt SF 2013 (cropped).jpg |caption = Wojcicki at [[TechCrunch Disrupt]] SF 2013 | office = 3rd [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of [[YouTube]] | term_start = {{Start date|2014|02|05}} | term_end = | predecessor = [[Salar Kamangar]] |birth_name = Susan Diane Wojcicki |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1968|07|05|mf=yes}}{{cite web|url=http://www.familytreelegends.com/records/39461?c=search&first=Susan&last=Wojcicki |title=California Births, 1905 - 1995 |publisher=Familytreelegends.com |date= |access-date=March 15, 2014}} |birth_place = [[Santa Clara County, California]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |education = [[Gunn High School]] |alma_mater = [[Harvard College]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]])
[[University of California, Santa Cruz]] ([[Master of Science|M.S.]])
[[UCLA Anderson School of Management]] ([[Master of Business Administration|M.B.A.]]) |years_active = 1999–present |salary = |party = |boards = |spouse = {{marriage|Dennis Troper|1998}} |children = 5 |parents = [[Stanley Wojcicki]]
[[Esther Wojcicki]] |relatives = [[Anne Wojcicki]] (sister)
[[Sergey Brin]] (brother-in-law, 2007–2015) }} '''Susan Diane Wojcicki''' ({{IPAc-en|v|uː|j|ˈ|tʃ|ɪ|s|k|i}} {{respell|vooy|CHIS|kee}}, {{IPA-pl|vujˈt͡ɕit͡skʲi|lang}};{{YouTube|a07s88y7f-k|"#DearMe: Susan Wojcicki, CEO of YouTube"}} born July 5, 1968) is an American technology executive. She has been the [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of [[YouTube]] since February 2014.{{cite news|last=Orescovic|first=Alexi|title=Google taps longtime executive Wojcicki to head YouTube|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2014/02/05/us-google-youtube-idINBREA141Y420140205|work=Reuters|date=February 5, 2014}}{{cite news|last=Gustin|first=Sam|title=Google Ad Chief Susan Wojcicki: 'The Book Isn't Finished'|url=https://www.wired.com/epicenter/2011/05/susan-wojcicki/|access-date=10 September 2011|newspaper=Wired.com|date=3 May 2011}} Wojcicki was involved in the founding of [[Google]], and became Google's first marketing manager in 1999. She was in charge of Google's original video service, and after observing the success of YouTube, proposed the aquisition of YouTube by Google in 2006. Wojcicki has an estimated net worth of nearly $500 million.{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/susan-wojcicki/#290a0e243ae3|title=#42 Susan Wojcicki|website=Forbes|access-date=2018-09-07}} ==Early life and education== Wojcicki is the daughter of [[Esther Wojcicki]], an educator of Russian-Jewish descent,{{cite web|last1=Tramiel|first1=Preeva|title=Esther Wojcicki: A Jewish mother of the tech revolution|url=https://jwa.org/blog/esther-wojcicki-jewish-mother-of-tech-revolution|access-date=1 August 2017}} and [[Stanley Wojcicki]], a [[Polish Americans|Polish American]] physics professor at [[Stanford University]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}} She has two sisters: Janet Wojcicki, (PhD, anthropologist and epidemiologist){{cite web|last1=Sellers|first1=Patricia|title=Before Google, the Wojcicki girls learned from Mom|url=http://fortune.com/2012/02/01/before-google-the-wojcicki-girls-learned-from-mom/|website=Fortune.com|access-date=16 December 2014}} and [[Anne Wojcicki]], founder of [[23andMe]]. She grew up on the Stanford campus with [[George Dantzig]] as a neighbor. She attended [[Gunn High School]] in [[Palo Alto, California]], and wrote for the school newspaper.{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2012/02/01/before-google-the-wojcicki-girls-learned-from-mom/ |title=Before Google, the Wojcicki girls learned from Mom |publisher=''Fortune Magazine'' |date=February 1, 2012 |first=Patricia |last=Sellers |access-date=October 4, 2014 }} Wojcicki's first business was selling "spice ropes" door-to-door at age 11. A humanities major in college, she took her first computer science class as a senior. Wojcicki studied history and literature at [[Harvard University]] and graduated with honors in 1990. She originally planned on getting a PhD in economics and pursuing a career in academia but changed her plans when she discovered an interest in technology. She also received her Master's of Science in economics from the [[University of California, Santa Cruz]] in 1993 and a [[Master of Business Administration]] from the [[UCLA Anderson School of Management]] in 1998.{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_17286427 |title=Susan Wojcicki: The most important Googler you've never heard of |publisher=''San Jose Mercury News'' |date=February 7, 2011 |first=Mike |last=Swift |access-date=October 4, 2014 }} ==Career== In September 1998, the same month that Google was incorporated, its founders [[Larry Page]] and [[Sergey Brin]] set up office in Wojcicki's garage in [[Menlo Park, California|Menlo Park]].{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402210041/http://www.google.com/intl/en/about/company/history/|title=Our history in depth – Company – Google|date=2012-04-02|access-date=2018-11-07}}{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/techinvestor/corporatenews/2007-07-04-google-wojcicki_N.htm |title=The house that helped build Google |publisher=''USA Today'' |first=Jefferson |last=Graham |date=July 5, 2007 |access-date=October 4, 2014 }} Before becoming Google's first marketing manager in 1999, Wojcicki worked in marketing at [[Intel Corporation]] in [[Santa Clara, California]],{{cite web|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3033957/the-woman-behind-the-superlatives-three-things-you-need-to-know-about-susan-wojcicki |title=The Woman Behind the Superlatives: Three Things You Need to Know About Susan Wojcicki |publisher=''The Fast Company'' |date=August 6, 2014 |first=Nicole |last=Laporte |access-date=October 4, 2014 }} and was a management consultant at [[Bain & Company]] and R.B. Webber & Company.{{cite web|url=http://ideas.time.com/contributor/susan-wojcicki/ |title=Susan Wojcicki |publisher=''Time'' |access-date=October 4, 2014 }} At Google, she worked on the initial viral marketing programs, as well as the first [[Google Doodle]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.anderson.ucla.edu/alumni/100-inspirational-alumni/susan-wojcicki-inspirational-100-alumna|title=Susan Wojcicki - "Inspirational 100" Alumna|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=''UCLA Anderson School of Management''|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=October 4, 2014}} Wojcicki also took part in the development of successful contributions to Google such as [[Google Images]] and [[Google Books]].{{cite web|title=Susan Wojcicki - CEO @ YouTube|url=http://www.crunchbase.com/person/susan-wojcicki|website=[[TechCrunch#CrunchBase|CrunchBase]]|publisher=[[TechCrunch]]}} Wojcicki grew within Google to become senior vice president of Advertising & Commerce and lead the advertising and analytic products, including [[AdWords]], [[AdSense]], [[DoubleClick]], and [[Google Analytics]]. [[YouTube]], then a small start-up, was successfully competing with Google's Google Video service, overseen by Wojcicki. Her response was to propose the purchase of YouTube. She handled two of Google’s largest acquisitions — the $1.65 billion purchase of [[YouTube]] in 2006 and the $3.1 billion purchase of [[DoubleClick]] in 2007.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/bizwomen/news/latest-news/2017/08/wojcicki-emo-could-deter-women-from-tech-careers.html?page=all|title=Wojcicki: Memo could deter women from tech careers|last=Stangel|first=Luke|date=August 10, 2017|website=BizJournals|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} ===CEO of YouTube=== In February 2014 she became the CEO of YouTube.{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/02/05/susan-wojcicki-youtube/|title=Google Ads SVP Susan Wojcicki Takes Over At YouTube|date= |access-date=June 12, 2014}} Wojcicki, called "the most important person in advertising",{{cite web|last=Peterson |first=Tim |url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/most-important-person-advertising-147489 |title=Google's Susan Wojcicki May Be the Biggest Name in Digital Advertising |publisher=Adweek |date=February 25, 2013 |access-date=March 15, 2014}} was named to [[Time (magazine)|Time]]'s 100 most influential people in 2015{{cite web|last=Grazer |first=Brian |url=http://time.com/3822770/susan-wojcicki-2015-time-100/ |title=The 100 Most Influential People |publisher=TIME |date=April 16, 2015 |access-date=October 5, 2015}} and described in a later issue of Time as “the most powerful woman on the Internet”.{{cite web|last=Luscombe |first=Belinda |url=http://time.com/4012832/meet-youtubes-view-master/ |title=Meet YouTube's Viewmaster |publisher=TIME |date=August 27, 2015 |access-date=October 5, 2015}} In the time that Wojcicki has been CEO of YouTube, the company announced that it had reached 1.9 billion logged-in users a month and that users were watching one billion hours a day.{{Cite news|url=http://mashable.com/2017/02/27/youtube-one-billion-hours-of-video-daily/#hs1RRV4k_Sqx|title=YouTube just hit a huge milestone|last=Hamedy|first=Saba|work=Mashable|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2017/06/23/youtube-1-5-billion-monthly-users-mobile-video/|title=YouTube Claims 1.5 Billion Monthly Users in Latest Ad Sales Pitch|work=Fortune|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en}} Since taking on the role of CEO, YouTube’s percentage of female employees has risen from 24 to nearly 30 percent.{{Cite news|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2017/03/how-to-break-up-the-silicon-valley-boys-club-susan-wojcicki|title=Exclusive: How to Break Up the Silicon Valley Boys’ Club|last=Wojcicki|first=Susan|work=The Hive|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en}} Wojcicki also oversaw the development and release of new YouTube applications and experiences designed to cater to users interested in family{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/02/23/hands-on-with-youtube-kids-googles-newly-launched-child-friendly-youtube-app/|title=Hands On With "YouTube Kids," Google’s Newly Launched, Child-Friendly YouTube App|last=Perez|first=Sarah|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en}} gaming,{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/aug/26/youtube-gaming-live-website-apps|title=Google launches YouTube Gaming to challenge Amazon-owned Twitch|last=Dredge|first=Stuart|date=2015-08-26|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} and music{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/11/12/9723496/youtube-music-app-offline-background|title=YouTube Music is here, and it’s a game changer|work=The Verge|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en-US}} content. She also oversaw the launch of YouTube’s advertisement-free subscription service, [[YouTube Premium]] (formerly known as YouTube Red),{{Cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2015/10/21/google-wants-you-to-pay-9-99-per-month-for-ad-free-youtube/|title=Google wants you to pay $9.99 per month for ad-free YouTube {{!}} VentureBeat|website=venturebeat.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-26}} and its [[Over-the-top media services|over-the-top]] (OTT) internet television service [[YouTube TV]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-39124092|title=YouTube takes on cable with new service|last=Lee|first=Dave|date=2017-03-01|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en-GB}} During her tenure, YouTube has tightened its policy on videos it regards as potentially violating its policies on hate speech and violent extremism.{{cite web|title=An update on our commitment to fight terror content online|url=https://youtube.googleblog.com/2017/08/an-update-on-our-commitment-to-fight.html|publisher=YouTube}} The more stringent policies came after ''[[The Times]]'' showed that "ads sponsored by the British government and several private sector companies had appeared ahead of YouTube videos supporting terrorist groups" and several large advertisers withdrew their ads from YouTube in response.{{cite news|last=Alba|first=Davey|title=YouTube's Ad Problems Finally Blow Up in Google's Face|url=https://www.wired.com/2017/03/youtubes-ad-problems-finally-blow-googles-face|newspaper=WIRED|date=25 March 2017}} The enforcement policies have been criticized as censorship.{{cite news|last=Hern|first=Alex|title=To censor or not to censor? YouTube's double bind|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/mar/21/youtube-advertisers-censorship|newspaper=theguardian|date=21 March 2017}}{{cite news|last=Cheong|first=Ian|title=Popular YouTubers React To Censorship Of ‘Controversial’ Content|url=http://dailycaller.com/2017/08/01/popular-youtubers-react-to-censorship-of-controversial-content/|newspaper=The Daily Caller|date=1 August 2017}} During the controversy surrounding [[Logan Paul]]'s YouTube video about a person that committed suicide, Wojcicki said that Paul did not violate YouTube's three strike policy and did not meet the criteria for being banned from the platform.{{cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/2/12/17006074/youtube-ceo-logan-paul-susan-wojcicki|title=YouTube’s CEO says Logan Paul doesn’t deserve to be kicked off the platform|last=Newton|first=Casey|date=12 February 2018|publisher=The Verge|accessdate=18 October 2018}} On October 22, 2018, Wojcicki criticized Article 13 of the [[Copyright Directive|European Union Copyright Directive]] that would give YouTube the sole responsibility for removing copyrighted content, saying it would pose a threat to content creators' ability to share their work.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/10/22/18008406/article-13-copyright-directive-youtube-susan-wojcicki-robert-kyncl|title=YouTube CEO says EU regulation will be bad for creators|last=Alexander|first=Julia|date=2018-10-22|work=The Verge|access-date=2018-10-27}} ==Personal life== Wojcicki married Dennis Troper on August 23, 1998, in [[Belmont, California]].{{cite web|url=https://www.paloaltoonline.com/weekly/morgue/community_pulse/1998_Nov_11.WEDDI111.html |title=Weddings |publisher=''Palo Alto Weekly'' |date=November 11, 1998 |access-date=October 4, 2014 }} They have five children. On December 16, 2014, ahead of taking her fifth maternity leave, Wojcicki wrote an op-ed in the ''Wall Street Journal'' about the importance of paid maternity leave. She is often quoted talking about the importance of finding balance between family and career. In addition to her US citizenship[{{cite web|title=Forbes Profile Susan Wojcicki|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/susan-wojcicki/|access-date=1 August 2017}} she is a Polish citizen.{{cite web|last1=Kafka|first1=Peter|title=New YouTube Boss Susan Wojcicki Talks Talent, Music and M&A (Q&A)|url=http://recode.net/2014/08/12/new-youtube-boss-susan-wojcicki-talks-talent-music-and-ma-qa/|website=[[Recode|Re/code]]|access-date=16 December 2014|date=August 12, 2014}}[https://www.wsj.com/articles/susan-wojcicki-paid-maternity-leave-is-good-for-business-1418773756 ''Paid Maternity Leave Is Good for Business''], The Wall Street Journal, 16 December 2014[http://next.gazeta.pl/next/7,151003,21560668,prezes-youtube-wlasnie-przyjechala-do-polski-a-to-dopiero-poczatek.html#BoxBizImg ''Prezes YouTube wlasnie przyjechala do Polski a to dopiero poczatek''], Gazeta.pl, 28 March 2017 Her grandfather, [[:pl:Franciszek Wójcicki|Franciszek Wójcicki]], was a [[People's Party (Poland)|People's Party]] and [[Polish People's Party (1945–49)|Polish People's Party]] politician who had been elected MP during the [[Polish legislative election, 1947]].{{cite web|url=http://www.prezydent.pl/aktualnosci/wydarzenia/art,551,prezydent-spotkal-sie-z-prezes-youtube.html|title=Oficjalna strona Prezydenta Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej / Aktualności / Wydarzenia / Prezydent spotkał się z prezes YouTube|first=|last=prezydent.pl|website=www.prezydent.pl}} === Advocacy === Wojcicki has been an advocate for several causes, including the expansion of paid family leave,{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/susan-wojcicki-paid-maternity-leave-is-good-for-business-1418773756|title=Paid Maternity Leave Is Good for Business|last=Wojcicki|first=Susan|date=2014-12-16|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}} the plight of Syrian refugees,{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/4373471/susan-wojcicki-world-refugee-day/|title=Susan Wojcicki: Refugees Are Trying to Escape Terror—Not Create It|website=Time|access-date=2017-10-26}} countering gender discrimination at technology companies,{{Cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/08/09/technology/youtube-ceo-gender-discrimination-response/index.html|title=YouTube CEO Susan Wojcicki on gender discrimination: It still hurts|last=Isidore|first=Chris|work=CNNMoney|access-date=2017-10-26}} getting girls interested in computer science and prioritizing coding in schools.{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/susan-wojcicki/tech-industry-gender-gap_b_9089472.html|title=Closing the Tech Industry Gender Gap|last=Wojcicki|first=Susan|date=2016-01-27|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-26}} == Awards == Wojcicki was named #1 on the [[Adweek]] ''Top 50 Execs'' list in 2013, which recognizes the top media executives within an organization.{{cite web|url=http://www.adweek.com/news-gallery/top-50-execs-who-make-wheels-turn-153431#1-susan-wojcicki-1|title=The Top 50 Execs Who Make the Wheels Turn|date=October 28, 2013|publisher=Adweek|access-date=March 15, 2014}} She was named #27 on [[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'s ''New Establishment'' list in 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/news/photos/2015/09/new-establishment-list-2015|title=New Establishment List 2015|last1=Bilton|first1=Nick|last2=Chafkin|first2=Max|date=October 5, 100 Most Powerful Women''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/susan-wojcicki/|title=Susan Wojcicki|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-11-15|language=en}} * In 2018, Wojcicki ranked #10 on Fortune's list of Most Powerful Women.{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2018/09/24/patti-davis-rihanna-fortune-most-powerful-women-2018-broadsheet-september-24/|title=Patti Davis, Rihanna, Fortune {{more footnotes|date=July 2011}} '''Syncom''' (for "synchronous communication satellite") started as a 1961 [[NASA]] program for active [[geosynchronous]] [[communication satellite]]s, all of which were developed and manufactured by [[Boeing Satellite Systems|Hughes Space and Communications]]. Syncom 2, launched in 1963, was the world's first geosynchronous communications satellite. Syncom 3, launched in 1964, was the world's first [[geostationary satellite]].<ref name = Gunter_Syncom123/>
In the 1980s, the series was continued as Syncom IV with some much larger satellites, also manufactured by Hughes. They were leased to the United States military under the Leasat program.
==Syncom 1, 2 and 3== [[Image:Syncom 2 side.jpg|thumb|First generation Syncom satellite.]]
=== Common features === The three early Syncom satellites were experimental spacecraft built by [[Hughes Aircraft Company]]'s facility in [[Culver City, California]], by a team led by [[Harold Rosen (electrical engineer)|Harold Rosen]], Don Williams, and Thomas Hudspeth.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/02/business/harold-rosen-dead-engineer-satellite.html</ref> All three satellites were cylindrical in shape, with a diameter of about {{Convert|71|cm|sp=us}} and a height of about {{Convert|39|cm|sp=us}}. Pre-launch fueled masses were {{Convert|68|kg}}, and orbital masses were {{Convert|39|kg}} with a {{Convert|25|kg|adj=on}} [[Payload (air and space craft)|payload]]. They were capable of emitting signals on two [[transponders]] at just 2 [[watt|W]]. Thus, Syncom satellites were only capable of carrying a single two-way telephone conversation, or 16 [[Teletype]] connections. {{As of|2009|6|25}}, all three satellites are still in orbit, although no longer functioning.<ref>{{cite web |title = U.S. Space Objects Registry |url = https://usspaceobjectsregistry.state.gov/Pages/Search.aspx |accessdate = 2009-06-25 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131006073413/https://usspaceobjectsregistry.state.gov/Pages/Search.aspx |archivedate = 2013-10-06 |df = }} (extremely slow site)</ref>
=== Syncom 1 === '''Syncom 1''' was intended to be the first [[geosynchronous orbit|geosynchronous]] communications satellite. It was launched on February 14, 1963 with the [[Delta (rocket family)|Delta B]] #16 [[expendable launch system|launch vehicle]] from [[Cape Canaveral]], but was lost on the way to geosynchronous orbit due to an electronics failure.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,898835,00.html | title=The Room-Size World (cover story) | date=May 14, 1965 | publisher=''[[TIME]]'' magazine}} </ref> Seconds after the [[apogee]] kick motor for circularizing the orbit was fired, the spacecraft fell silent. Later telescopic observations verified the satellite was in an orbit with a period of almost 24 hours at a 33° inclination.
=== Syncom 2 === '''Syncom 2''' was launched by NASA on July 26, 1963<ref name="D-2911"/> with the [[Delta (rocket family)|Delta B]] #20 launch vehicle from Cape Canaveral. The satellite successfully kept station at the altitude calculated by [[Herman Potočnik|Herman Potočnik Noordung]] in the 1920s.
During the first year of Syncom 2 operations, NASA conducted voice, teletype, and facsimile tests,<ref name="D-2911">{{cite web |url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19650019255.pdf |title=Television Tests with the Syncom II Synchronous Communications Satellite (NASA technical note D-2911) |first=Varice F. |last=Henry |first2=Michael E. |last2=McDonald |work=ntrs.nasa.gov |publisher=[[NASA]] |date=July 1965 |accessdate=2014-12-07}}</ref> as well as 110 public demonstrations to show the capabilities of this satellite and invite feedback. In August 1963, President [[John F. Kennedy]] in Washington, D.C., telephoned Nigerian Prime Minister [[Abubakar Tafawa Balewa]] aboard {{USNS|Kingsport|T-AG-164|6}} docked in [[Lagos]] Harbor; the first live two-way call between heads of government by satellite. The ''Kingsport'' acted as a control station and uplink station.
Syncom 2 also relayed a number of test television transmissions from Fort Dix, New Jersey to a ground station in Andover, Maine, beginning on September 29, 1963. Although it was low-quality video with no audio, it was the first successful television transmission through a geosynchronous satellite.<ref name="D-2911"/>
=== Syncom 3 === '''Syncom 3''' was the first [[geostationary orbit|geostationary]] communication satellite, launched on August 19, 1964 with the [[Delta rocket|Delta D]] #25 launch vehicle from Cape Canaveral. The satellite, in orbit near the [[International Date Line]], had the addition of a wideband channel for television and was used to telecast the [[1964 Summer Olympics]] in [[Tokyo]] to the [[United States]].<ref> {{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,876272,00.html|title=For Gold, Silver & Bronze|date=October 16, 1964|publisher=''[[TIME]]'' magazine}}</ref> Although Syncom 3 is sometimes credited with the first television program to cross the [[Pacific Ocean]], the [[Relay 1]] satellite first broadcast television from the United States to Japan on November 22, 1963.<ref name="NASA-SP-93">{{cite web|url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19660009169_1966009169.pdf|title=Significant Achievements in Space Communications and Navigation, 1958-1964|year=1966|work=NASA-SP-93|publisher=NASA|pages=30–32|accessdate=2009-10-31}}</ref>
Turned off in 1969, Syncom 3 remains in [[geosynchronous orbit]] as of December 2012.<ref name = INFOSATELLITES3/> In 40 years it has drifted 8 degrees to the west, to longitude 172.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.infosatellites.com/syncom3-satellite-tracking-norad-858.html | title = Real time tracking and positioning of Syncom 3 satellite 1964-047A identified by Norad 858}} Requires Javascript.</ref>
== Syncom IV (Leasat) == [[Image:Syncom LEASAT.jpg|thumb|Syncom IV, Hughes owned US Military Leasat]] The five satellites of the 1980s Leasat (Leased Satellite) program (Leasat F1 through Leasat F5) were alternatively named Syncom IV-1 to Syncom IV-5 and called HS 381 by the manufacturer.<ref name=summer1994>https://web.archive.org/web/19990505230020/http://www.spaceway.com/uplink/archive/up942/leasat942.html</ref> These satellites were considerably larger than Syncoms 1 to 3, weighing 1.3 [[tonne]]s each (over 7 tonnes with launch fuel). At {{Convert|4.26|m|sp=us}}, the satellites were the first to be designed for launch from the [[Space Shuttle]] payload bay,<ref name=fas>http://fas.org/spp/military/program/com/leasat.htm</ref> and were deployed like a [[Frisbee]].<ref name=Beginnings>http://www.hughesscgheritage.com/leasat-beginnings-and-significance-dr-boris-t-subbotin/</ref> The satellites are 30 rpm [[Spin-stabilized satellite|spin-stabilized]] with a despun communications and antenna section. They were made with a solid rocket motor for initial perigee burn and [[hydrazine]] propellant for station keeping and spin stabilization. The communications systems offers a wideband UHF channel (500 kHz bandwidth), six relay 25 kHz channels, and five narrowband 5 kHz channels.<ref name=hughes-boeing>https://web.archive.org/web/20091230151101/http://boeing.com/defense-space/space/bss/factsheets/government/leasat/leasat.html</ref><ref name=sky>http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/leasat.htm</ref> This is in addition to the fleet broadcast frequency, which is in the military's X-band. The system was used by military customers in the US and later in Australia. Most of the satellites were retired in the 1990s, but one would remain operational until 2015. During the [[First Gulf War]], Leasat would be used for personal communications between Secretary of State [[James Baker]] and President [[George H. W. Bush]],<ref name=ott /> but was more typically used by "mobile air, surface, subsurface, and fixed earth stations of the Navy, Marine Corps, Air Force, and Army."<ref name=hughes-boeing />
Hughes was contracted to provide a worldwide communications system based on four satellites, one over the continental United States (CONUS), and one each over the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]], [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]], and [[Indian Ocean|Indian]] oceans, spaced about 90 degrees apart.<ref name=fas /> Five satellites were ordered, with one as a replacement. Also part of the contract were the associated control systems and ground stations. The lease contracts were typically for 5-year terms, with the lessee having the opportunity to extend the lease or to purchase the equipment outright. The [[US Navy]] was the original lessee.
Leasat F1's launch was cancelled just prior to lift-off, and F2 became the first into orbit on August 30, 1984 aboard ''[[Space Shuttle Discovery|Discovery]]'' on shuttle mission [[STS-41-D]]. F2 was largely successful, but its wideband receiver was out of commission after only 4 months.<ref name=ott /> F1 was launched successfully on November 8, 1984 aboard [[STS-51-A]]. This was followed on April 12, 1985 by Leasat F3 on [[STS-51-D]]. F3's launch was declared a failure when the satellite failed to start its maneuver to geostationary orbit once released from ''Discovery''. Attempts by Shuttle astronauts to activate F3 with a makeshift "flyswatter" were unsuccessful.<ref name=ott /> The satellite was left in low earth orbit, and the Space Shuttle returned to Earth. This failure made front-page news in the ''[[New York Times]]''.<ref name=rescue>http://www.hughesscgheritage.com/the-leasat-rescue-mission-steve-dorfman/</ref> Hughes had an insurance policy on the satellite, and so claimed a total loss for the spacecraft of about $200 million, an amount underwritten by numerous parties.
However, with another satellite planned to be launched, it was determined that a space walk by a subsequent Shuttle crew might be able to "wake" the craft. The best guess was that a switch had failed to turn on the satellite. A "bypass box" was hastily constructed, NASA was excited to offer assistance, the customer was supportive, and the insurance underwriters agreed to fund the attempt at space salvage – a first.<ref name=rescue/>
On August 27, 1985 ''Discovery'' was again used to launch Leasat F4, and during the same mission ([[STS-51-I]]) captured the 15,000 lb stricken F3. Astronaut [[James van Hoften]] grappled and then ''manually'' spun down the F3 satellite. After the bypass box was installed by van Hoften and [[William Frederick Fisher|Bill Fisher]],<ref name=winter1993>https://web.archive.org/web/19990507015718/http://www.spaceway.com/uplink/archive/up964/leasat964.html</ref> van Hoften manually spun the satellite up. Once released, the F3 successfully powered up, fired its perigee motor and obtained a geostationary orbit. (This scenario would play out again in 1992 with [[Intelsat 603]] and ''[[Space Shuttle Endeavour|Endeavour]]''.) While F3 was now operational, Leasat F4 soon failed and was itself declared a loss after only 40 hours of RF communications.<ref name=ott>http://www.hughesscgheritage.com/leasat-f5-the-final-chapter-andy-ott/</ref><ref name=winter1993 />
The stricken F4 did not remain a complete failure. Data from F4's failure permitted the saving of F1 from a premature failure. Since all of the Leasats are spin-stabilized, they have a bearing point that connects the non-rotating and rotating parts of the spacecraft. After F4's communication failure, it suffered a spin lock while attempting to jostle the communications payload: the spun and despun sections locked together.<ref name=ott /> Remembering this second failure of F4, and with F1 beginning to wear out at the spin bearing, it was decided to "flip" F1 every six months to keep the payload in the sun.<ref name=ott /> Thus F1 went on to operate smoothly for its remaining life and never encountered a locked despun section.
Leasat F4 was subsequently powered down and moved to a graveyard orbit with a large amount of station keeping fuel in reserve. This was fortuitous; when another satellite suffered a loss of its fuel ten years later, Hughes engineers pioneered the use of alternative propellants with Leasat F4. Long after its primary mission had failed, F4 was powered back on to test whether a satellite could be kept on station using nonvolatile propellants.<ref name=ott /> F4 was used to perform numerous tests, including maneuvers with oxidizer for propulsion once the hydrazine ran out.
The fifth and last Leasat (F5), which was built as a spare, was successfully launched by ''[[Space Shuttle Columbia|Columbia]]'' mission [[STS-32]] on January 9, 1990. The last active Leasat, it was officially decommissioned on September 24, 2015, at 18:25:13 UTC.<ref name="intelsat20150924">{{cite web |url=http://www.intelsat.com/blog/industry-news-blog/another-intelsat-satellite-serves-customers-for-more-than-25-years/ |title=Another Intelsat Satellite Serves Customers for More Than 25 Years |publisher=Intelsat |first=Sharyn |last=Nerenberg |date=January 24, 2015 |accessdate=September 25, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150926034550/http://www.intelsat.com/blog/industry-news-blog/another-intelsat-satellite-serves-customers-for-more-than-25-years/ |archivedate=September 26, 2015 |df= }}</ref> F5 was one of the longest-serving and most successful commercial satellites. Towards the end of its 25-year life, F5 had been leased by the [[Australian Defence Force]] for UHF service.

== Further reading ==
*{{cite web | url = http://www.boeing.com/defense-space/space/bss/factsheets/376/syncom/syncom.html | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101111082736/http://www.boeing.com/defense-space/space/bss/factsheets/376/syncom/syncom.html | archivedate = 2010-11-11 | title = Boeing. Satellite Development Center. Syncom. The world's first geosynchronous communications satellite. | quote = For example, no transistor amplifiers existed, and transistors then didn't work well at frequencies above 70 MHz. We had to get up to 10 GHz. So we used a chain of diode frequency multipliers, or doublers. | accessdate = 2013-03-11 }}

Glover's page about NASA Experimental Communications Satellites] * NASA Goddard Space Flight centre descriptions: **[http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1963-004A Syncom 1] **[http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1963-031A Syncom 2] **[http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1964-047A Syncom 3] * Gunter's Space Page: **[http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/syncom-1.htm Syncom 1, 2, 3] **[http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/leasat.htm Leasat 1-5 (Syncom-IV 1 to 5)]

revision.text:
{{Advert|date=February 2011}} {{Infobox company | name = Terso Solutions | logo = [[Image:Terso logo.jpg|250px|Terso Solutions]] | type = [[Privately held company]] | key_people = Joe Pleshek, [[CEO]] | industry = Radio Frequency Identification ([[RFID]]) Technology | num_employees = 48 (2017) | foundation = 2005 | location = [[Madison, Wisconsin]] | homepage = {{URL|http://www.tersosolutions.com}} }}
'''Terso Solutions, Inc'''., located in [[Madison, Wisconsin]], USA, is the developer and distributor of an automated system for storage and distribution of high value research reagents and medical supplies. Terso first developed a reagent stocking system, which uses [https://www.impinj.com/about-rfid/what-is-rain-rfid/ RAIN] [[radio frequency identification]] (RFID) tags along with secure access control, linked to the internet. These combined technologies allow inventory to be securely tracked and managed remotely.<ref>2005 [http://www.madison.com/archives/read.php?ref=/tct/2005/11/15/0511150112.php Report: Promega spins off RFID unit.] ''The Capital Times''. November 15. Business, 8B. Retrieved on July 7, 2008.</ref> [[Image:TersoOffice.JPG|thumb|right|300px|Terso Solutions, Madison, WI, USA.]]
== History == Developed initially as an on-site inventory supplier for Promega products, the privately held Terso Solutions, Inc. was spun off from [[Promega]] Corporation in 2005. In February 2010, Terso Solutions formed Terso GmbH in Mannheim, Germany, in response to increasing demand for its RFID units in Europe.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tersosolutions.com/news/7/56/Terso-Solutions-Expands-Global-Operations-and-Opens-Branch-in-Germany/ |title=Terso Solutions Expands Global Operations and Opens Branch in Germany |author= |date=8 February 2010 |work=Terso Solutions |publisher= |accessdate=28 July 2011}}</ref>
Terso Solutions employs 48 people. The company holds 17 United States patents, 2 European patents, and 3 Japanese patents.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tersosolutions.com/resources/patents-trademarks/|title=Terso Solutions|website=Terso Solutions|language=en|access-date=2017-06-02}}</ref> Joe Pleshek has been CEO of Terso Solutions since 2008.
==In Healthcare== Terso Solutions offers RFID-enabled cabinets, refrigerators and freezers as part of an automated inventory management system for healthcare. Terso’s products are typically used in cath labs, emergency rooms, and hospital supply rooms. Benefits hospitals realize from Terso’s units include improved regulatory compliance, expiration date management, reduced manual inventory processes and secure, 24/7 real-time access to high value inventory.
==In Life Science== The company’s RFID-enabled cabinets, refrigerators and freezers are used by biotechnology and biopharmaceutical laboratories. Labs and the manufacturers and distributors who supply them use the company’s products to gain more secure control over inventory, ensure product integrity through 24/7 temperature monitoring, expiration date management and by eliminating surprise product outages.
Terso also offers an RFID-enabled Smart Stockroom, which is marketed as an efficient 24/7 system for managing medical and research inventory. The room-based solution is designed to allow users to access products anytime without manual sign out, and to capture all of this data in real-time.
==About Radio-Frequency Identification== Radio-frequency identification or RFID tags work by emitting radio waves, either actively or passively, which allow the object or item carrying the tag, to be identified. Active RFID tags involve a power source such as a battery and emit signals, while passive devices require a scanning or reading device for signal identification. Tags can be worn, attached to or implanted in an object. Microchips used in pet animals such as cats and dogs work by [[RFID]]. When an animal is found, if it has a microchip bearing an RFID device implanted, the animal can be scanned and the owner’s contact information transmitted. Terso Solutions supply cabinets and freezers provide temperature-controlled storage and on-site location of supplies. This allows 24/7 access to research reagents, as well as automated inventory control. The cabinets and freezers provide secured access, so that only authorized users can remove the products. This controlled access, combined with RFID tags, allows real-time tracking of products and is designed to allow easy inventory assessment and timely restocking as the supply of reagents is depleted.
==RFID and Transplant Medicine== A new and rapidly evolving field of medicine surrounds the collection and distribution of tissues for reuse in human patients, including tissues as diverse as eyes, musculoskeletal tissue, eggs, sperm and blood stem cells. Experts agree that the field, in its infancy, has the ability to improve the quality of life, or in some cases preserve life for many patients. As the list of potential patients grows, so does the complexity of collecting, storing and distributing high quality tissue. The number of regulatory agencies involved in tissue procurement and distribution itself is substantial, including the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations (JCAHO) and the American Association of Tissue Banks (AATB). These agencies cooperatively define the processes by which biological materials from donors are collected, stored, distributed and used. Storage of such tissues in RFID-enabled cabinets and freezers is an ideal means of ensuring proper storage of, tracking both supplier and user of, and maintaining inventory of such tissues.<ref name="Bio Storage 2008">Bio Storage: Keeping track of tissue in the supply chain (2008) ''Material Management in Health Care''. 30-2.</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External sources==
* [https://www.tersosolutions.com/ Terso Solutions] * [https://www.promega.com/ Promega]
[[Category:Biotechnology companies of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in Madison, Wisconsin]] [[Category:Radio-frequency identification companies]]

{{Infobox company | name = UCL Business PLC | logo = UCL Business logo.gif | logo_size = 140px | caption = | type = [[Public limited company]] | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = 2006 ([[London]]) | founder = | defunct = | location_city = London | location_country = [[United Kingdom]] | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = | industry = [[Technology transfer]] | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = [[University College London]] | divisions = | subsid = | traded_as = | homepage = [http://www.uclb.com/ UCL Business] | footnotes = | intl = }}
'''UCL Business PLC''' ('''UCLB''') is the [[Technology transfer|technology-transfer]] company of [[University College London Hospital NHS Foundation Trsust]] (UCL) and is headquartered in [[London]], [[United Kingdom]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uclb.com/content/aboutuclb/|title=About UCL Business|publisher=UCL Business PLC|accessdate=31 October 2010}}</ref> It is a wholly owned subsidiary of UCL and is responsible for conducting technology development and commercial transactions for the university. It is based on [[Tottenham Court Road]] in the [[London Borough of Camden|Camden]] area of [[Central London]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uclb.com/content/contact/|title=Contact us|publisher=UCL Business PLC|accessdate=31 October 2010}}</ref>
==History==
UCL's first technology-transfer company was founded in 1989 as UCL Ventures.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v419/n6904/full/nj6904-04a.html|title=Calling for entrepreneurs London|accessdate=31 October 2010|publisher=Nature|date=19 September 2002}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v419/n6904/box/nj6904-04a_bx1.html|title=Box 1. Transferring ideas|accessdate=31 October 2010|publisher=Nature|date=19 September 2002}}</ref> UCL Ventures merged with the technology-transfer company of the [[Royal Free Hospital]], Freemedic plc (founded in 1993) to form UCL Biomedica PLC.
UCL Business PLC was created in August 2006 through the merger of UCL BioMedica with UCL’s internal knowledge transfer department, also known as UCL Business. The former UCL Business had been established to provide a link between UCL's academics and industry, and to aid the development of commercially valuable technologies arising from UCL, whilst UCL BioMedica had been established to commercialise opportunities arising from UCL’s biomedical research strengths, as well as to conduct clinical trials. The integration of the two technology transfer activities created a single organisation focused on delivering the complete commercialisation process from patent registration and support for the creation of new businesses, through to licensing and sales of technologies to industry partners.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uclb.com/lib/tmp/cmsfiles/File/Brochures/UCLB_Brochure_Single_Pages.pdf|title=UCLB: Building Commercial Success|publisher=UCL Business PLC|page= 7|accessdate=8 December 2010}}</ref>
UCLB provided advice and a grant support to [[Siavash Haroun Mahdavi]] in helping him to establish the robotics company Complex Matters.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theengineer.co.uk/news/siavash-mahdavi-university-college-london/300366.article|title=Siavash Mahdavi, University College London|accessdate=31 October 2010|publisher=The Engineer|date=15 June 2007}}</ref>
In January 2011, BioVex, a cancer vaccines company spun-out of UCL in 1999, was sold to [[Amgen]] for $1 billion.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/14/world/europe/14iht-educLede14.html?pagewanted=1&_r=1|title=University Finds Rewards and Risks in Business Start-Ups|accessdate=25 April 2011|publisher=The New York Times|date=13 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sciencebusiness.net/news/74714/UCL-spin-out-sold-to-Amgen-in-$1-billion-deal|title=UCL spin out sold to Amgen in $1 billion deal|accessdate=25 April 2011|publisher=Science Business|date=27 January 2011}}</ref>
==Operations==
===Spin-out companies===
UCLB has equity stake in all of its companies, the majority being spin-outs arising from technologies developed across the full range of faculties within UCL, including biomedical, biotechnology, engineering, mathematics, physical sciences and build environment companies. These include Ark Therapeutics Ltd, Arrow Therapeutics Ltd, Biovex Ltd, Canbex, Domainex Ltd, Evexar Medical Ltd, Genex Biosystems, Intercytex, Medic-to-Medic, Pentraxin Therapeutics, PolyMASC Pharmaceuticals PLC, Proaxon, Spirogen Ltd, Stanmore Implants Worldwide Ltd,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uclb.com/content/companies/biopharmcomps/|title=Biomedical and Biotechnology Companies|publisher=UCL Business PLC|accessdate=8 December 2010}}</ref> Advanced Design Technology, AS Built Solutions, Bloomsbury DSP, Endomagnetics, EuroTempest, Ixico, Quantemol, Senceive, Space Syntax, Zinwave.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uclb.com/content/companies/biopharmcomps/|title=Engineering, Physical Science and Built Environment Companies|publisher=UCL Business PLC|accessdate=8 December 2010}}</ref>
==External links== * [http://www.uclb.com UCL Business]
==References== {{Reflist}}
